reviewText:
Very disappointed at this game. MAIET is the worst company to have hold of this game; They ban you for 40 years on an Early Access Beta- Some of these players paid over hundreds of dollars, I know one who's paid over $200 and is banned- because of you getting caught up in a glitch not caused by you - A hacker once ruined the Tesla Shop RNG weapon winning section and glitched it for everyone making them get free rolls for a main prize in the shop - and they call you a hacker afterwards when it was never your fault you got a bunch of weapons from their own game being exploited due to ♥♥♥♥ coding and server control! In addition, they don't care about their players; they treat you like ♥♥♥♥ and only care about money. It's a Pay 2 Win game; blazing weapons that do 10 HP damage over 3 seconds in addition to bullet damage from the shop and have double the stats as the other weapons? Totally not Pay 2 Win. If you are going to play this game, DO NOT INVEST ANYTHING in it. They will treat you like trash and ban you with 0 conflict nor ♥♥♥♥s or apologies given.

Other than that, here are some extra features to make the game good! (Start sensing sarcasm, after all this IS a bad rating):

-P2P Hosting: Amazing, just get a group of 4 people all sitting next to each other, group up, and queue to get the 0 ping host advantage while the other team gets 300+ ping!

-♥♥♥♥♥♥ room controlling: You get in a match, crash. You finish a match, crash. You find a match, crash. You can't control anything, you have to wait an hour for a match, no one queues in ranked play because of this ♥♥♥♥.

-Unbalanced classes: That's right, I'm throwing out the old Elena complainer here. But here's why: She's a gunslinger, weak at melee and is supposed to die and get caught by an assassin chasing them with melee easily- WAIT A SECOND, NOPE, UNCLE MAIET'S LOGIC THINKS, lets put 30% melee damage resistance and 150% extra melee damage at level 20 on the weakest melee character and make her the best one now! Not only that, lets make her have the ability to outdash spam a melee asassin while being able to fire a 6 shot kill super accurate rifle while in manuevers! Perfect, now she's the best ranged AND melee, AND WITH AN ADDED TWIST, the nade spam! Not only can you non-stop fire the nades, they also stun you, can stunlock if fired non-stop, and each one easily does 100 damage.
Asassins? My ♥♥♥, I can out asassinate enemy players with my Max, A SHIELD TROOPER.

-♥♥♥♥♥♥ limited campaign mode!: Gunz 1 had a million dungeon quests and made the hard dungeons require a brain for unlocking them a first place, as well as being hard. But Maiet. Maiet, why. Why do you do this. Lets put levels that can be solo-ed and don't even need skill/thinking to finish. Same boss attack patterns, same map and objective, and same enemies and levels. Where's the variety!? Gunz 1 has a better PvE system than yours, and that game is so ♥♥♥♥ing old compared to your just released ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥!

-Not convinced yet? WE'LL THROW IN, the Tesla Shop, and limited playing features! (4 characters only, 3 game modes only)
-Tesla Shop: Get ready, for the best weapons to be won at a 1/200 chance, with 2000 players rolling all for one item at once, and for each roll taking 5 hours to obtain! Unless you choose to pay, $50 for only 10 rolls at a 1/200 chance! It's such a good deal, we'll even throw in a limited edition 6 hours common-tiered timed weapon! Anddddddd Don't forget! This system is so ♥♥♥♥, it got exploited by hackers who got away with hacking, and instead got innocent players- some who paid over hundreds of dollars on this game- banned permanently because they tried to win one weapon, so the next time you try to win a weapon, be careful and dont get banned for 40 years IN AN EARLY ACCESS BETA!

-4 Characters: Make sure to ENJOY the same 2 weapons over and over!

-3 gay modes: Speaking of variety, LET'S PLAY, Team Deathmatch, Team Deathmatch Elimination, and Team Deathmatch timed!

So folks, get ready, GET READY FOR THE SECOND DUEL- err I mean DEATHMATCH- IN A 4V4 ONLY ROOM which has a 50% possibility to crash with 0 ping hosts you're playing with hosting from Antarctica to make your ping freeeeeeeeze to 500!

Such an improvement in features compared to Gunz 1. Ohhh man it's just too great to be true.

At First Gunz: The Duel was a Third-Person Action game from the humble origins of Free-to-Play gaming
The game became a close memory that many of us hold close to our hearts, bringing a unique game from the wave of free-to-play gaming from korea in the 2000's. It provided Fast-Paced gameplay, with a high skill curve due to a glitch in the game that allowed players to execute complex inputs. Mainly known as K-style, it truely provided a hardcore" expirience due to it's difficulty in execution and strict timing. reviewText:
Good game with a terrible community. I've played this game since the Steam release, played in most servers/regions, and have seen so many people come and go. The game has been abandoned by the original developers and sold to a company that, so far, has only made sure the servers stay up and running. This, however, does not stop the community from  playing. The good matches that you can get into between legitimate players and games with friends are the only reason I can still enjoy this game.

The combat is great, movement is fluid, glitches (for the most part) and unintended merchanics add to the gameplay, and good matches can be very thrilling. The game isn't impossible to learn, but many new players make the mistake of thinking this is a melee game. Good movement and aim will get you farther than anything else.

Practice rooms also exist and provide most players with what they need to learn the game, if they are willing to ask. That being said, it is also possible to simply learn the game by just constantly queuing normals and base everything off what you experience in matches. More experienced players in this game often play together, but there are many who solo queue just to balance out the matchmaking. You will fight the same people often, no matter which modes you play, and most people know who each other are.

The biggest issue is that the game has no anti-cheating measures and the community is filled with players that hack, or are willing to party with those who do. That being said, there's still a good amount of players who play fair. You can still get good games more often than not by arranging premade games between groups or from just queuing, but many hackers in this game go out of their way to ruin the experience for others.

Overall, the game itself is fine, but can take a while to get the hang of. If you have decent aim and learn the movement mechanics, you'll be fine. If you run around trying to melee better players, you won't have much fun. At the time of writing this, I have the most kills in ranked/normal match queue at almost 70,000 and roughly 3,400 hours of playtime. Although a lot of that time is waiting in queue, I have experienced and tried pretty much everything the game has to offer. I hated this game at first and can now say it is the most enjoyable game I have ever played. GunZ 2 is, at the very least, worth trying.

reviewText:
well, I don't think I've ever given this game a review.
I do not recommend it. Not because I think it's a bad game, but because the way it's handled.

lotta prollems.

Hacking
Hacking's an issue, I don't remember one hack free week of gameplay when I  was into it. I'm sure with all these hack threads in my absence, it's only gotten worse.

Updates/support
This game hardly updates, when it does it's mostly a balance patch, and personally I don't mind, balance patches I think, are a good thing, the prollem is they do it wrong.

Also, the focus of this game has changed region several times, first in closed beta for korea(totally different game then), then kill it off and bring a new beta to EU(resembling what we have today), then bring the Open beta to the US on Steam, then pull it off steam in EU and sell it to Aeria games which doesn't seem to care about the game in the end as it somehow died there and is now back up in steam in EU I think? I don't even know, AND NOW IT'S IN MALAYSIA!

Cash Items
While I would prefer cash items to not exist, and I personally don't think the Tesla system is bad in the sense of earning a weapon, it makes it a real hard sell for people wiling to put money in the game, you're paying, to get a chance at getting a  weapon. You can find yourself spending hundreds to get everything you want.

Netcode
So we're still using the Host system. I got to play on the dedicated server in US-West for a while, but not every game that night was on the dedicated server and afterwards I think they just droped it.

What's good? Gameplay.
It's fast paced, it's intuitive, honestly gameplay alone, it's not that bad, just a few tweaks with the games hit and block stun and melee combat in this game would be great imo, The melee combat is fun, it's just not good. This game does incorporate strategy in Team Elimination mode and it's always great to have a team that works together just right, Ivans can snipe opponents just out of the hallways in Mansion, Elena's can locate any hiding opponents with her E-skill, Renas and Waynes can provide a distraction to assist in kills for their team, very effectively. Yeah, the game really isn't that bad for competitive play, but unfortunately, there isn't much competition and the Host system in this game basically makes one member on either team really hard to kill, and it makes it too easy for them to kill you, so you will have to precede with caution when you fight against the host.

Btw, anyone expecting this game to play like Gunz1 will be disappointed, they're totally different games.


Conclusion
I will close my review saying what I said before, I cannot recommend this game, I like it, I've had a lot of fun playing it, but it just doesn't deserve the love that neither I nor the many veteran players that have stuck with it give it today, because maiet just doesn't know what to do, it's like they're throwing the game everywhere just to see who likes their product the most instead of actually working towards making it a truly good product.

reviewText:
Extremely fun at times, but ruined by a couple of major issues. Too many flaws for me to recommend.

- Unreliable gambling shop for acquiring upgraded weapons. Under no circumstances should you be required to wait an entire day to attempt to gamble for a weapon with unreasonable odds. Even when maximizing your odds you are unlkely to get a weapon, you can only buy crystals in bulk and hope for the best. If MAIET wants to turn G2 into a cash cow, could they at least make it consistent? Put the blues at 3.99, yellows at 14.99. The people who got lucky from the shop or have hundreds of dollars to waste love it, but nobody else does.

- Bad netcode. Zero attempt at lag compensation. You need to aim where they will likely be by the time your ping reaches the host, rather than aim where the enemies actually are.

- Even worse host & matchmaking system. MAIET is intent on keeping it P2P either because they're unwilling to fund a revamp or they don't realize just how ridiculous P2P is for the region the game is on.

- Lack of progression/direction. Weapon stats are hard to compare, and many of the bars are extremely misleading. Having to datamine to get the actual stats for comparison is unacceptable. Convert the bars to numbers, make the differences between weapons more noticeable and less clearcut as to which one is best for use, and do something to further weapon upgrade progression beyond Get the green gear
date: then gamble for a couple days straight and hope you get lucky for the next tier of weapons". Make it so you can buy the blues for gold or USD
recommended: or achievements where if you get a certain number of kills with the green weapon
hoursPlayed: you get the blue version of it
voteText:
and so on with the yellow version.

- The list goes on. Rena & Max are extremely strong in certain ways but terrible in most others. You need to pay for the other classes. No duel mode. Some cases of bad map design. Almost nobody prefers Time Assault. No custom games. No server browser. Ad nauseum. You get the idea. The game seems to have been released too early.

Don't let my ranting confuse anyone

At least it's free to play, but you may waste your time or get frustrated with your own nostalgia.

reviewText:
They took some of the mechanics of Gunz (running on walls and general acrobatics) and made an overall generic 3rd person shooter as a sequel.

Levels are dull and uninspired, almost none of the levels from the first game have been remade.

They added Q and E style ablities and unlockables for each class.. (Original game was just skill + equipment)
They added classes.. (Original game you decided your 'class' by what you equipped)
They took out K-style and everything associated with it (Advanced animation exploit that added a huge gameplay mechanic)

The gameplay just feels slower in general as well. Though you can still run on walls and flip around, the level designs don't really encourage it, with many more corridors, uneven surfaces, and smaller areas, it's usually more effective to stay planted on the ground, and play it as a typical 3rd person shooter. Acrobatics are only useful in this game to get away quickly, but serve little use in direct combat. Unlike the original game which feature larger levels with alot of open spaces and the acrobatics were used for getting around quickly, and mixed in with combat fluidily due to the nature of the gameplay and levels. In this sequel useing acrobatics in combat just causes a mess due to the close proximity you always tend to have to other players.

Compared to the first game there is a slight delay to every action, that as a diehard fan of the original, makes Gunz2 just painful to play.

It's free, and it's a full experience. It's a quality game that you may enjoy.
As a fan of the original, I can't recommend this, it feels watered down, generic, and generally boring.

reviewText: As it's own game, GunZ 2 is fun to play due to the fast paced combat and relatively high skill cap. Unfortunately it falls flat on many other aspects, especially the playerbase. There are hackers everywhere amongst the small (think <1000) amount of players, who simply ruin the fun of the game too frequently for GunZ 2 to be the successor it needed to be. On top of that, the game does not have any of the addicting features the older GunZ had, which was mastery of keystrokes/innovative movement system and a cult following. Might be fun for a few days or hours, but my final decision would be to stay away in the first place.

reviewText: This game is supposedly a sequel to one of my favorite early shooters, but I just don't feel it. Putting the server issues aside, the matchmaking system is horrible in the sense that I am at the moment level 2, and i'm matched up with level 10+ clans. This reiteration of GunZ puts almost no emphasis on guns, instead focusing almost completely on melee combat. The gunslinging class is helpless against every melee class, and the only counter to melee classes is the tank class. All melee weapons will stun-lock you, and some even have an AOE effect where a melee hero can easily take out two or even three teammates in close proximity. It's not unheard of for an entire team to empty their clips on a melee class just for them to rush behind you and take each of you out.\n\nThis game looks great on paper, and is visually a big step up from the original GunZ, but until classes are fairly balanced, this might be one game you're going to want to stay away from.

reviewText:
GunZ the Duel was a very interesting and fast paced experience. Instead of being bound by classes, you were free to experiment and customize your character as you see fit. Your main limitation being weight, your loadout would usually be quite balanced. If you wanted to carry a rocket launcher, heavy machine guns, and a sword for maximum DPS you might have to head out without armour, for instance! You could go full melee, full ranged, or anything inbetween. It was a beautiful system that encouraged you to try everything it had to offer.

As time went on, players also adopted K-Style. Using animation canceling, players could perfect a complex series of keypresses that'd allow for seamless traveling across any given map - and unrivaled combat prowess limited only by a K-styler's skill level and dedication. Both K-Stylers and the more average vanilla-gameplay style worked hand-in-hand and made for amazing and intense matches.

Questing was a bit confusing, but entertaining and challenging all the same. So much freedom, new gametypes and updates every so often, it was fun while it lasted. Near the end of its life, GunZ the Duel introduced an almost MOBA-style gametype that allowed players to get better gear than the real-money store offered. This killed the sales and forced" them to shut the original GunZ down before GunZ 2: the Second Duel was released. It seemed like the timing was a little too perfect and on-purpose
date:
but I digress.

GunZ 2: the Second Duel changed some things up.

Movement was made to be more accessible. They moved away from the steep learning curve of K-Style
recommended: opting for a system where you can run up walls and get around with but a few taps of the spacebar. This seems alright. Where I think it begins to fall apart
hoursPlayed: is the addition of classes. For me
voteText: this destroyed much of the experimentation and customization that made GunZ so balanced and fun. With these classes

reviewText:
-----------DON'T F***ING MAKE PEER TO PEER ACTION GAMES-----------------
=thank you=

So, my story with gunz goes waaaaay back when i was 7 years old or so playing in a low end computer and cheap internet, even with all that i was still able to hit some good combos and playing with friends was so fun, the game was balanced enough (even some premium weapons being kinda stupid) there were lots of guns to choose and equip a single character (breaker ftw) the coop mode was pretty good and the pvp was awesome

The only problems i saw with gunz was the female defense that was slightly better..and that made no sense at all..and the graphics that even in the release were bad, but WHATEVER, it was fun, addicting, playing with friends was a blast, combos were really hard to master but so rewarding when you finally manage to slash your sword, switch to a shotgun quick, shoot and get the kill (it sounds easy but good luck actually doing that lol)
Even with a low end pc and cheap connection i could still have loads of fun through YEARS (400$ notebook and 1MB connection for 10 bucks per month to be exact) my latency stood around 50-100, it's not good

Well, fast forward, new high end pc, great new broadband high speed connection and BOOM Gunz2 OH MY GOOOOOD, THAT AWESOME GAME I PLAYED WHEN YOUNGER IS HAVING A SEQUEL...well...it is having a bad, unbalanced, poorly developed, badly designed, broken and boring sequel..

-----------------------GUNZ2 IN A NUTSHELL---------------------------

Login, feel nostalgic, get confused from the characters, what does he do, who is she ? why a shield ? wich one is better ? jump in the tutorial..waste your time..play coop, amaze yourself with the mind blowingly stupid AI, go to a deathmatch, hear how dozens of players had intercourse with your mother, get angry at that host that never changes because he has 0 lagg but the others are suffering from 500+ latency, see that happening again..and again..and again..and again..then after some time start seeing cowboys that press Q and kill you (it should be called aimbot instead of one shot one kill..it's really the same), g3t stunl0ck3d m8, 1t's d MLG cowboy 420 bl4z3 1t

Okay, let's talk about what's wrong in this game
-Bad character modeling
-PEER TO PEER ? SRSLY ?
-Poorly designed maps
-WORST COMMUNITY EVER, LOOKS LIKE THE AVERAGE PLAYER IS 5 YEARS OLD (AND I THOUGHT COD WAS BAD)
-One-button-instant-kill stunlock sniping cowboy
-Meh gunfights
-TERRIBLE melee combat
-Peer to peer doesn't work for ANY GAME, AT ALL
-Horrible ambience
-UI is one of the worst i ever saw
-Weird button mashing mobility
-Pretty much useless tutorial wich doesn't explain not even a quarter of the game
-Matchmaking is really annoying
-God mode bug that happens pretty often
-It locks your region so if you want to try playing maybe EU to see if there is a good host or better community there or your region lacks good hosts..maiet doesn't care
-Did i mention peer to peer shouldn't be used ?
-Oh, i did mention
-Good, i need to make this clear

What i actually found good
-Soundtrack..it's pretty good..we have to admit..
-Effects, the fire, gunshots and slashes effects are somewhat cool
-If you're lucky enough to get good hosts or you have a stupid fast internet connection, if you don't get MLG cowboys stunlocking you 24/7 and play with a full party..it can be kinda fun
-The game really can improve..this can just be a shaky start but one thing is pretty clear, it will NEVER become what gunz used to be

Note to Maiet: Nerf Max to make the game more balanced..then release the strider class ? really..? is this some kind of prank ? some bad joke ?

reviewText:
GunZ 2 is pretty much a remastering of a age old action TPS, GunZ. GunZ was a fast paced action TPS that involved either great amounts of skill, or great amounts of panicing. That game was fast paced, from the start to finish of any match.

Many advanced players would be sporting their respective fighting styles, and many newer players will be resorting to classic methods of run and gun. GunZ presented many ways to tackle problems; to rush in with your sword and come out like a bad ♥♥♥, or have a heated gun fight and blow some lead into your opponent.

GunZ truly was a to the book, fun game. And here we have, GunZ 2 being released. Now at it's current stage, GunZ 2 is very much in it's early access/ alpha stage, so this review may not be valid if it so changes drastically, or proves me wrong in the future.  Granted, from the time I have played so far, here is what I have gathered.And this may all well just be an extended first impressions, so take it with a grain of salt.

From the get go, the first thing I noticed, was the uniquely different art style that GunZ 2 has. It's a lot less, dark" shall I say than GunZ 1 in my opinon. But GunZ 2 does have slightly better graphics than GunZ 1

reviewText:
Okay now that I can actually get into the game, it's time to give it a fair review.

GunZ 2: The Second Duel is the successor to the fast-paced third person shooter GunZ, which was by far one of the best experiences I've had with shooters. GunZ is a very unique game which requires good positioning, dodging, and accuracy. Now with GunZ 2, there are many changes from the first game, both good and bad.

Before I begin, I am neutral on the removal of K-Style, I believe that it both helped and killed the game, creating elitism where people were making smurfs" and just completely obliterating the new players. I believe it is what killed the community
date: and it was a decent idea by Maiet to remove this ability. However
recommended: one of the best parts of K-style was the incredible pace that your character was able to move at. It was absolutely amazing to be able to slash shot from wall to wall while shooting people. It gave such an "epic pro" feeling. Also

This game has just been released, and has a long road to travel until completion, but I do recommend taking part in the fun!

reviewText:
Ok. Now I believe most server errors are gone and people can finally join the game. I've been playing for quite a long time and this game is incredibly fun. Veteran players of the first Gunz will not experience the same moves and same mechanics, this is a completely different game but, however, I believe there will be new awesome moves aswell just like the first one.
The class concept is simple: Every class is overpowered. They are equally overpowered so it's balanced. I don't believe people will start using only one class anytime soon (Maybe most people will choose Ivan, idk why).
The game modes are really cool. They are:
Team deathmatch Self explanatory. Two teams of 4 players battle against each other, you respawn when you die and the team that reaches a score of 450 first wins.

Team Elimination 5 rounds where players wont respawn. If you die you have to wait for the next round. It's cool because you end up being careful on where to go and people will stick together to make a good team. And a team with different classes will always be better than one with only one class.

Team Assault I like this one most! Unfortunately it's got only one map. It's pretty much an attack x defense mode where the attackers have to make their way through 3 gates, destroying them with bullets or swords while the defensors have to stop the other team. At the end of the round the roles will switch: attackers will defend and defenders will attack.
It's cool because people are pretty much obligated to work as a team to make their way through the given time (10 minutes) and hold the other team from doing it in less time than your team.

The classes, as I mentioned, are equally overpowered. I say that because each one got an special effect or damage that will get people on their nerves. I haven't tried all of them yet, I'm going for it as soon as possible but I assure there's no best class in this game.

If you're smart enough to know what Early Access" stands for and you like GunZ you should definitely try. I have loads of fun in this game every time I play it"

reviewText:
IMPORTANT: Although this is a sequel to GunZ 1, it is almost 0% similar in content (No K-Style). So get that out of your head, and don't start complaining that it's not the same.

GunZ 2 is a game that's different from most others currently out there, and is rather fast-paced as well. Some people will love it for the challenge, and others will hate it cause they can't handle being wrecked for the first week or so of playing.

Gameplay: Run on walls, dash all over the place, 1 melee and 2 ranged equipped at once. Currently 5 unique classes (daggers, swords, bats, shields, whips, SMGs, rifles, snipers, miniguns, flamethrowers, etc).

FLAWS:
- P2P Hosting
- Various bugs still in need of fixing
- Lack of customiztion (needs more cosmetics, etc)
- The basics of a v1.0 game

reviewText:
This game is really fun. I recently got back into it, but I spent a lot of time on it when it was in beta and honestly it was a pretty crappy experience.

I won a few of those weekend events and got the special badges by no lifing but the amount of hackers and laggy hosts was awful. However, now that the game is live and out of beta I decided to try it out again and I spent a good 4-5 hours playtime without noticing a single hacker and there are not nearly as many lag problems as there used to be.

They also did really well with balance. It feels a lot more like I ♥♥♥♥ed up when I die rather than Max being OP or Rena having infinite dashes.

I definitely recommend this game. It's not nearly as brutal on your hands as the first Gunz but it's definitely still just as fun.

It also has a very high skillcap to it, and I would say the entry barrier is pretty high too if you're not much of an FPS/TPS player. It's a very fast paced game. Definitely worth trying out though!

reviewText:
The game is fun, despite its current unbalances, and small map/gamemode roster. But those will be ironed out with time, as it lives. The animations are good, the map design is very decent (ignoring a few flaws of a young game), and maps from the Original GunZ make their way into this iteration too. The campaign is a good challenge too, despite very little reason to play it.

But then there's the Cons:
Stunlocking is too easy to accomplish as some classes, basically guaranteeing the lockee's death.
And then theres the community, rather small at the moment, but currently full of people who exploit the stunlocks, and spawn kill extensively, ruining the fun for the people who just want to play the game, not tryhard it.

Apart from these small issues, its a fine game, and i recommend it.

reviewText: A good game design, however lag and server problems make the game unplayable, as you get shot through walls, and die almost immedietly when you see an enemy. reviewText:
The second part of the infamous Gunz game where it is known for its high skill cap and fast combat system with a various of weapons at your disposal. I played the first game and loved it but had to stop due to the amount of hackers that flooded it unfortunately. When I heard a 2nd game was being made I was pretty ecstatic knowing one of my all time favorite 3rd person shooter was making a reboot. Unfortunately... I was dissappointed.

Before I begin, this is a side-by-side comparison review between Gunz1 and Gunz2. For those of you who have NOT played Gunz1, then you will have NO idea what i'm talking about and won't know what I felt when playing this game. Though I do bring up other points that are a by itself" case in terms of Gunz2 gameplay but that is up to you to decide if you agree with me or not.

Without further ado
date:
here is my Gunz2 review:


First off... classes... WHY?
It's sad to say this game tried to mimic the currently famous/mainstream shooters like COD and BattleField by introducing classes that uses specific weapons and has different playstyles. To make it worse
recommended: if you want to play the other classes you need to proceed to buy them. Just... no.\nGunz1 was fun because you could buy w/e weapon you wanted
hoursPlayed:
try out different combinations and play it your own way.
With the class system it chooses FOR you limiting your playstyle and forcing you to either make a new account or pay to play another character if you get bored with the one you've been grinding for who knows how long.

Oh wait did I say grinding? yep... there is a level system in this game.
Every other level or so you unlock skills that are a necessary core playstyle for your class such as... I don't know... being able to save yourself mid-air when an enemy knocks you up which was a clear distinction in Gunz1 if you were going against a bad player or not.
This also brings me back to playing the other characters... oh boy now you got to level THEM up to.
I wanted to play a 3rd person shooter and go crazy
voteText: not grind and be forced to level my character up to access his abilities to fully experience the CORE of the gameplay.\nGunz1 had a level system but each level unlocked new weapons for you to try out
helpfulPercent:
NOT necessary skills.

This brings me to playstyle itself.
I've reached level 6 before stopping (reasons which i'll explain later) and noticed a distinct play style everyone incorporates. Rush the enemy
votesHelpful: knock them down using melee combos
votesTotal:
then proceed to fill them with lead using your gun.
You see in Gunz1 most of the time you did NOT see a gun pop out unless it was a quickdraw. Most of the time you would see people flying around everywhere with their swords out using wall-slash climbing techniques or butterfly sword fights. Melee is completely obsolete in this game other than to do what I've mentioned above and to use your .... *ughs* ultimates/active abilities.

Oh boy... lets bring in some abilities that takes about the same skill level of a 13 year old targetting a mob in World of Warcraft and give it 1-shotting capabilities. That's right folks. Once you reach 3 bars in your power guage
votesFunny: you get access to a specific class based ability that pretty much 1-shots or gets close to it if you land it... which is pretty much easy since every single melee hit manages to stagger you and the game isn't as fast paced as it used to be.\n\nSpeaking of fast paced... this game is slow as BALLS compared to Gunz1. Seriously
commentsCount: they literally dumbed down the gameplay for people of all skill levels can somewhat compete with one another. When the point of a game is to try and out play your opponent in terms of wit and playstyle and you dumb that down so there is hardly any learning curve and the combat system is generic and repetitive
column16:
you get Gunz 2.

Oh and what a way to complement the slow gameplay with laggy servers...
Laggy servers that are chosen beforehand in a system where a "host" is designated to provide a specific region that best optimizes the rest of the players internet stability. Just as warning
column17:
that internet stability is nonexistant 3 out 5 times where hosts are constantly being shifted to different players due to the horrible connectivity issues.

Pay to Win.
Yep folks
column18: this is a pay to win game. Gear is HEAVILY weighted in this game where a gear difference is enough to shift a balance dramatically to one team. For example: if you were to have a stand off with the enemy without moving
column19: the person with better gear WILL kill you before you even break his shield. In this aspect
column20: outplaying the enemy means nothing since he becomes a versatile one-man army being able to TAKE hits and dish out twice as much damage than you can.\n\nBut wait
column21: there's more!\nThe queue system and lobby system
column22: I admit
column23: is one of the better ones I've seen that incorporates it. It's fast
column24: it's clean
column25: and gets you in a game without any trouble.\nHOWEVER
column26: the matching system is broken to all hell. There is no brackets in this game
column27: as far as I can tell
column28: and you WILL get paired up with people 2x
column31: 5x + level than you. This is the main reason I quit the game because I constantly got paired with high leveled people that HAD the gear
column34:
and so forth. It was entirely one sided in most matches I've played since there is always a high level in yours or the enemy's team.

I'm pretty sure there are more points I missed but constantly thinking about Gunz 2 just keeps filling me with dissappointment and anger.

As a disclaimer
column35: this review is purely OPINION. That's right folks... OPINION. So if you get butthurt because you enjoyed the game and I didn't then keep your comments to yourself. If there are people out there who do find this game fun then good for you. I'm not bashing the people who play this game

reviewText:
As much as I would love to see this game as the first GunZ, I do NOT believe that I can make an exception on this one.
First of all, GunZ's community is one of the worst. It includes hackers, kids, hackers, kids, a few GunZ 1 veterans, hackers & kids. In addition to that, there are hackers.
The game has been dead since its release; it is hard to find a decent match with the available matchmaking option, and if you do, you end up in a DUEL, most likely a 2v2, where your opponents will have at least a dozen levels over you. That means a few things; they'll have better weapons, and they'll be more skilled.
Aside from the gameplay & matchmaking, full maxed out graphics are decent. They aren't bad, they actually look good for a Free-To-Play game. This is, by far, the online thing that I would recommend for this game.
In the end, I do NOT recommend this game.

DG| Light, from DeadlyGaming.com

reviewText: GunZ 2: The Second Duel, is a fast paced 3rd person FPS showdown between a selection of four different classes with unique skills, weapons, and skillplay. Although the game is currently in beta, many problems exist with achievements, the host system, and broken mechanics. Despite the joy that comes out of playing GunZ 2, I have concluded that it would be better not to play this game. The reasons I mentioned - particularly miniscule at first glance - are the core reasons why the game has such a small community and unsatisfactory results/reviews. Despite a new sense of intense gameplay that can be derived from the game, with no indication of future success or plans, the time spent on the game will most likely be wasted. I am not downgrading the game far enough that I would call it unplayable; however, unless dynamic changes are in store for the future, this game will disappear. (This may change over time, but how closely related the mechanics and systems are of the korean version, I doubt any plans that fixes any of the above issues will come of it.)

reviewText:
TOO LONG DID NOT READ:
I would advise you hold off on playing it until MAIET patches some of the extremely unbalanced classes and bugs.

If you are expecting a game like the original Gunz then this is probably not the game for you, the two games are vastly different in both mechanics and playability, it is also quite different from the Korean version which i have also played.

I shall start with the gameplay:
Until the last patch I felt aside from some major problems with the character Rena it was a pretty solid game with an easy to pick up yet somewhat harder to master. One of my personal gripes is that at times feels spammy, by this I mean it is tad of a button masher feeling more like a 3d Street Fighter where you can move around the map, but with less of the charm and skill of the Street Fighter series.
There is also a lacking of block abilities many attacks cannot be blocked or doged which makes for quite some frustration.

There are some good point to the combat, for instance the wall running ability is pretty much flawless feeling insanely smooth, there are some minor issues with the dash feature in conjunction with the wall run both graphically and functionally.
On that same point it is to be noted that the dash is one of the main elements of batted, by default you have to double tap the W key to increase your movement speed, this can be used to do the only effective dodging in the game.

Onto the weapons, these themselves are quite fun but to use any weapon aside from the defaults you must craft them with a generation system, by which you use ores gained from completing achievements in game in the Tesla Shop, unlike a normal system you cannot craft the weapons that you specifically want you must input the ores into a machine which then pops out a random wep.

One last thing to do with the gameplay, K Style was all but removed from the game. Granted it wasn’t really supposed to be in the first owing to the fact it was a series of glitches but after seeing the number of people who enjoyed using it, would have been nice to see MIAT bring it back in some form.

I shall move onto the graphics and playability levels:
The Graphics are not great even on the best settings, yet they are drastically different on high than the low setting which is in all honesty an affront to the eyes.
There is a major problem with the fact that until you engage in a match you are unable to set the game to fullscreen mode.
Gunz 2 lacks the playability level for me, I started out loving the game but after about 20 hours it just started to feel like a pointless button mashing grind.
Not too many other features to discuss but this review is getting long so I shall cut it short.

*Update as of Jan 28 2015*
MAIET has not patched anything, there remain constant hit detection issues, graphical problems, a lack of dedicated servers, infinate z glitches etc.
Since the introduction of Rose there hasn't been anything really done to the game, there are still very few maps and its become hard to even play the game.

reviewText:
Best free steam game Imo.

Requires greater skills than anything else you tried. The game is fast so your reaction needs to be as quick as a snake, but at the same time, you have to be good enough to kill an hawk from below.

Only 4 vs 4, but that's more than enough. Maps are small so there's like 0 downtime. An other game where you don't want to feed the enemy or you will be the reason for the loss of your team. In melee, it's more like a fighting game since you can also block and use special abilities to pin your opponents down. Cool none automated combos.

I expect to see a greater amount of players duking it out in the near future with larger maps too,

My only problem with this game is the balance.
The big guy is overpowered with his flamethrower and you can't even knock him down while he spit fire. I think this is unfair and it automatically makes him the best character in melee and he don't even have to use his melee weapon. That character is as buffed as Sylvester Stallone and he is just as agile as the other characters combined with the fact that he is more resistant and he may block with his tower shield for ever.

reviewText: I feel the premium shop Tesla Shop" is a scam. It cost 5$ for 12 coins. It cost 7 coins for a roll. And the chances are slim that you will get a item that is permament. That right you are mostlikely going to get a item that last 6 hours from the time you got it. So if u want the full affect of your $2.50~ item you have to play for 6 hours non stop. It will not be ther tomorrow. Out of the 15 items i got in the premium shop [Gave me extra coins cuz i did the BETA] i got zero permament items. Granted i did it before the ODDs were below 100/200. But no one told me to do that at the time. The game did not explain what the system was either. I had to browse the fourms and find a comment someone said. So i "Gambled" 2 more rolls and made shure it was below 100/200 and i still got 6 hours items. Now the derps defending the game and saying 70/200 [never happens].\n\nThe game mechanics are ok. Needs a bit more scripts to be fluid and not a chance this will happen. Some characters are OP with stagger lock abilities. And its not yet supported by Steams Anti Cheat system. I loved the origional more because of the shop

reviewText:
I really want to like this game. The wall jumping is very fun and fluid controls make accomplishing these feats better then they are in Warframe. I like the PVE Missions they have, the mix of melee and ranged and the pace of the matches. I also really like the gladiator mode that is melee only.

What I don't like?
some of the abilities aren't very reliable such as Rena's Q. Some of the better items defintly make it a PayToWin game.

But I could look past all that... my biggest problem?

Despite 400 people being online I've currently been waiting in a que for 5 minutes. Every day for the last six days I have logged in and tried to play with very limited success, ques taking an abnormal long amount of time. It's hard to like a game whe you can't play it. Fix the que times and I would like this game more.

reviewText:
So sad that a game I anticipated for so long would disappoint me this way.

Now let me just say that I was hyped for this game ok. I literally fell out of my chair when I saw this game announced for real. I waited patiently for it and finally when it was released I quickly downloaded it and nearly had a nerdgasm...but it was not to be.

I live in Jamaica and according to what I read, this game uses some sort of P2P connection which is more affordable than say hosting a server in various countries. This however has led to my game client being unable to even find 1 multiplayer game. I literally let it run as long as it could possibly run (I think it was well over 300 seconds) and it said it was unable to find a game in any of the 3 game modes. Surprisingly enough I saw between 70 and 100 users online at the time so I figured finding one would be a breeze. But no, it couldn't find one.

The one time I had a little bit of enjoyment in the game was when I created a Mission lobby and after about 10-15 minutes 1 person joined and we played a little bit with a few minor setbacks. He had been searching for a game forever and was unable to find one either. He was from another Caribbean island also. Never have I ever played a game that I am unable to join up with other users. How am I to give this game a proper rating if I can't even create a multiplayer lobby and play by myself?
I'm really not interested in the story, just give me the ability to play with some people, that's all.

reviewText:
......I got nothing.....I have absolutely nothing. I have nothing to say about this travesty of a game....other than the fact that it's not good. Not good at ALL! There are so many problems I don't even know where to start! So I'll just list them as I go along.

1. The game's coding is straight up sh*t, honestly, I've been in a match where a guy exploited a glitch that allows him to get a vantage point without anyone being able to hit him, and the spawning is so bad that players literally camp where you just spawned.

2. The single player campaign is completely worthless, all you do is 1. Shoot guys, 2. Shoot guys, 3. Shoot guys, and possibly 4. shoot up a boss. THAT'S IT! Repetitive and boring, and the AI is SO dumb! Some even literally run against a wall!!

3. PVP connection.....oh GOD the connection, there wasn't a single, I repeat, NOT A SINGLE time I wasn't lagging in a match, and guess what, other's didn't have the disadvantage and they end up killing the laggy players with 300+ ping while they only have 20- ping

4. The weapons are either not powerful enough, or overpowered to the point of straight up SPAMMING and the ammo runs out too quickly, so chances are, you're probably screwed without ammo

5. The game is suffering from MicroVolts-Character-Syndrome, meaning if you want to play as another character, you have to play over 100,000 in game currency to play as the character, and even then, there's still the chance that you'll be screwed because of the glitch I told you about eariler.

6. The characters themselves are unbalanced, and the game is too stupid to balance out the teams! Seriously, there was even a team full of sniper dudes and another with two demolition ladies, a minigun guy and a cowboy, guess who won?

All in all, ♥♥♥♥ game, nothing is redeemable about this.

reviewText:
Do youself a favor, avoid this game. Deleted after playing 1 hour.

Graphics : lousy for a 2014 game. I set everything at max and game still looked like it came from 2010. No physics, no decals, everything is just bad.

Gameplay : worst part of it. Practically no improvements over the Gunz 1. You're forced to pick 1 character from the start, given bare amount of information about classes, and requires insane amount of coins to add character. Tutorial too easy, enemy AI is dumb, but they can swarm you and takes 3 shots to kill you.
Health and shield drops disappear after 5 secs, can't even complete 1st campaign mission with a party of 5.
Barely anyone is playing this game. Exp and coins are insanely hard to come by.


complete disappointment.

reviewText:
Pros: Jiggly breasteses. Wall running. Sick soundtrack.

Cons: Rena is OP is all hell, matchmaking is horrendous (lvl 1's being matched with 20's, wtf m80?), and the more you play the more obvious it is that this game is pay to win. Early access and they've gone straight to p2w. You don't stand much of a chance against anyone in a match with more than one level 10+ in a match because all the abilities you don't have yet don't let you. If you decide to download it and play, stay away from Gladiator Mode unless you're willing to put it a decent amount of hours grinding for Refined Ore to get a decent sword, or willing to pay for swords. The community is kinda already headed downhill. Plenty of people complaining about facing noobs, or being matched with higher levels, not the god awful matchmaking system. Frustrations all around.

I hope this game gets better. I loved GunZ 1, I played it for nearly the entirety of my middle school career. I want to love GunZ 2. Until matchmaking is fixes, toons are balanced, and it's playable without having to shell out 30 bucks to get decent gear, don't play this game.
I'm sticking with it for now, but I shouldn't.
Come on MAIET, don't mess this up. (any more than you have)

reviewText: A very good turn based social ♥♥♥♥♥♥me that requires a lot of skill as you must hold down primary attack with your primary weapon as long as you can in the general direction of your enemy. As the game chooses a host for the game lobbies, there is very little lag if you are hosting which is good. The amount of customisation is astounding with choices ranging from a curved sword to a straight one. Important notifications are never missed as they scroll across your screen obstructing your view of everything else that is unimportant i.e everything else so you will always know when there is a maintenance which happens very often as MAIET clearly knows how to manage servers and strive to achieve the best game performance they can by constantly taking the servers down to fix the very few issues the game constantly has. The game feels more responsive than a blind, deaf and crippled elderly about to kick the bucket which is really impressive and certainly a next generation improvement. The death animation is amazing as it feels painful to watch, a once lively body suddenly a corpse ragdolling across the map because of a few invisible bullets is incredible. MAIET must have done a really great job as the servers are constantly full which indicates people want to play this game. The only thing that I could possibly criticise is the title of this game, GunZ 2. This implies it is a sequel to another game but I do not believe that this is actually a sequel to anything. If you didn't get the major tone of sarcasm, this game is a complete ♥♥♥♥ing let down and should not carry the name 'GunZ'. The new physics engine so good the game actually breaks and becomes unplayable, wall running is so easy now, you can run through the walls. MAIET, how the ♥♥♥♥ to you down grade like this. Low skill cap as any 'special' moves require ZP and just one press of a button to instantly kill anyone infront of you or escape certain death because you got caught. MAIET takes pride in GunZ 2's biggest strength being freedom of movement, yet this is clearly a very weak point as movement is choppy and too static because they tried too hard in removing animation cancelling. Wisdom comes from age and experience comes from time and work, a few (hundred) years developing this and MAIET managed to become ♥♥♥♥♥ier and the work they have produced is basically just every amateur TPS out there with a few 'perks'. MAIET, did you spend a good year or two perfecting the breast jiggle physics or something? High speed, hard to detect explosions in a small area is a great idea as well as having a stealth skill that takes too long to use on the spot and no where to set up. Also melee in this game is incredibly unbalanced and it is much easier to 'trap' someone now. Any settings higher than low is a party bag full of seizures and frame drops although it does look quite nice, for a bunch of  pictures. reviewText:
This game is a lot of fun despite the time it will take you to become really good. This is practically a completely different game than the first one even though it may look very similar. There are classes in GunZ 2 which I didn't like at first but now that I have 300+ hours sunk into it I have changed my mind. Each class brings something different from the abilities you unlock as you level to 20 to the weapons available to that specific class. There are currently 5 classes and at least 1 more coming. The game isn't without it's flaws; the Tesla Shop feels awkward for a free-to-play game and still feels almost border-line pay-2-win despite the recent buff to the rate at which you aquire the currency used to purchase Tesla Shop gear as it'll take the average player a few months to deck out your character in full Blazing/Lightening equipment. It's not a huge advantage but it's enough to force you to stay out of Ranked until you get a set yourself. Each class feels incredibly unique and appeals to different play-styles. As a beginner, you'll probably want to pick up either Elena, Max, or Ivan as they have the lowest skill-ceiling (least amount of effort in order to do decently) but in the hands of a skilled player they're all balanced fairly well.

The developers have pushed through a lot of criticism early in beta and have been working hard to bring out more content and shape the way the game feels. Their efforts have really been paying off and the latest balance and content patches have been excellent. Aside from the Tesla Shop and more custom game options (which was just released so I'm sure it'll come), my only complaint is that there needs to be more clothing and weapons purchasable for gold as well as cosmetic gear that people can buy to distinguish and customize their character. You can mix and match clothing pieces to suit your tastes.

If you're a GunZ 1 player who's looking for a carbon-copy clone, GunZ 2 is not it and that's for the better. You no longer have to be able to press 6 keys per second to effectively evade bullets, ect. While the game might feel slower-paced to people that were used to GunZ 1, it's actually just as fast or even more-so once you learn to utilize wall-running and objects to get around the map instead of dashing on the ground. Wall-running and the like is something EVERY player will have to master if they want to become a great player and it's so much fun once you do.

Hope this review was helpful and that some of you who're interested will give this game a shot because it's simply fantastic!

reviewText:
In the short time that I've played the game there are two things that have jumped out at me.

The first is that the game has very fun, fast gameplay. The game definitely rewards skill and with great precision you can kill even the highest levelled players. The combat can be frustrating when you get completely stunlocked by another player, which is especially frustrating for a new player who does not understand the game yet and is attempting to learn the mechanics. In terms of the gameplay, this game is very good.

The second thing that I have noticed is that this game is EXTREMELY unbalanced. Although the game claims that it will match you with players of equal level and skill"
date: it is lying to you. At level 1
recommended: you will get matched with level 20 players that have full sets of gear and will tear you apart. This makes learning the basics of the game very difficult. It also makes the game somewhat unfair. They definitely need to fix the matchmaking in this game ASAP. It deters new players (like myself) almost immediately from wanting to play the game any further. The gameplay is great and so is the game itself
hoursPlayed: but this level of unbalance and the feeling of it being unfair from the very beginning has made me turn my decision and not recommend this game for the moment. The learning curve is too great for you to be thrown into a game full of high level players.\n\nI hope that this gets changed soon

reviewText:
50% of my time on GunZ 2 is from waiting to get in.
Other than that let's get into it.
This really isn't like the first game which kinda puts me off, but if you're new to the GunZ universe, you may find yourself easily entertained.  Melee is seriously downgraded especially with the variety of characters' special skills.  Most of the time, their special skill with a full meter will OHK you which is seriously annoying and absolutely does not require much to do.  People spamming their guns at you and waiting for that meter fill up just to do that OHK is what I'm talking about.  Gun play is boring and can't be experimented at the fast rate as it was in the first GunZ because certain guns belong to their respective classes, which I think is massive ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.  This is also definitely pay-to-win because of that well-known cash shop that every F2P game seems to have.  I'd very much rather pay $20~ to play this game rather than having it F2P and dealing with people who can't afford to be OP and with people who can apparently afford to be OP.

In all honesty, they should have kept it like the first GunZ, or at least keep it running because this is just a boring mess.  This game is just good as a time-waster now, nothing more.  Wish I could give this a neutral rating but I guess I'll stick to a positive.

reviewText: Oh god...I remember playing the first game through the ijji launcher back in what...2007? What a great Free to Play game this was. What more could a 7 year old boy ask for then flying ninja dudes, guns, and swords. While that game was great in it's prime now we have GunZ 2: The Second Duel. Though I have not poured hundreds of hours into this game like I did the first one, as a veteran player I can say this is a completely different game in terms of controls and graphics among other things. This game has it's own style of play unlike all of the mechanical exploits the first one was abused with, so don't come into this game thinking you already know what you are doing, you need to relearn how to play. Now that steam has gotten a hold of the game this game is not as hardcore as it used to be...but that does not mean it is not fun! Whether you are a veteran of the past GunZ games or a complete rookie to the series I can almost guarantee that you will have a blast playing this game.\n\n8/10

reviewText:
Host method will be the undoing of this game.

What will inevitably cause this game to flop will be the single host method of connectivity. What's the problem with it and what are the alternatives? As most GunZ 1 players know, GunZ was a P2P method of gameplay but it didn't for a long time get anti-lead measures.

As of now, whoever the host is gets extreme priority on hits, and whoever lives closer to the host is the runner up. Meaning that competition will always be tilted in the favor of the host & closer players, aka coast to coast competitions will always be unbalanced.

Futhermore, rather than just having every player connect to one another P2P (not quite sure why not opt for this if you're just going to use a worse and more biased form of this), which would result in equal gameplay between all players, i.e., everyone gets equal priority in games.

Or simply consider measures for setting up dedicated servers & the ability for players to purchase dedicated servers of their own if MAIET doesn't have the money to fund such an endeavor.

While there are some other glaring issues, I believe that the current method of networking will inevitably turn players off from the game, even if its other issues are fixed.

P.S. Have been through T Gunz 2, Eu Gunz 2 and some private servers in between. MAIET has been aware for a while about the inefficiency of the system but has not yet decided to re-work the networking. As the team says their focuses are:

* More new character classes  -- should focus on balance and quality rather than abundance
* More language support (Spanish, Portuguese, and etc..)  -- don't know why this is one of the main focuses...
* More game modes -- could be fun
* More levels (maps) -- this one is a given
* More character customization items (cosmetics) -- don't know why this is a focus right now
* Enhancement on UX (user experience) features -- better late than never
* Stabilizing compatibility and optimization -- too bad fixing the networking isn't part of this

reviewText:
I started playing, the controls are pretty clunky, and combat seems off somehow, with dashing being basically useless, though the developers for some reason expect you to use it. In fact, it's so dumb and useless, the developers had to create a special area in the campaign missions just so you have a reason to use it. Double jump would have been better. Every time I attacked a group of enemies, my character would finish her combo, and then be counter attacked and die because she feels the need to spend 10 seconds trying to look cool with an animation.

After creating my character and playing a few missions and death matches, I realized I had spelled my screen name wrong, and found that there was no real way to go back to the character screen.  So I had to exit the the entire game, and after restarting, I found that you only get the choice of one character, which you can't delete. This game just has a bad format for trying to make it easy for the player. I immediately exited the game, and uninstalled. I don't even wanna try. Even the tutorial was dumb and useless, take a lesson from TitanFall's tutorial, which was both intuitive and interesting.

I did not really have fun playing this, and I loved the first Gunz.

reviewText:
Gunz 2 (Sequel to Gunz: The Duel) is a fantastic high speed third-person shooter. The game offers several different characters which each represent a different class. The gameplay itself centers around two main modes, a competitive team deatchmatch style mode, and a cooperative vs ai mode. The gameplay itself is easy to learn but hard to master and just when you think you've figured it out, someone comes along to school you (like me :P) The game offers an old-school shooter feel with powerups and health pickups scattered around the maps. The game features a different mix of gunplay and swordplay for each character.  You can purchase much of the costumes and weapons with in-game currency and if you're a very skilled player, wont need to upgrade very much at all. It offers a challenging third person shooter experience thats free, so its worth a shot. But if you arent very good at shooters to begin with, you might have a hard time getting any fun out of it. (Since you'll be dead)

THE GOOD
+ Good graphics for an F2P
+ Fast Paced Third Person Action
+ Melee is a blast when you master it
+ Oldschool shooter feel (not another COD)

THE BAD
- Not recommended for beginners
- Community leaves much to be desired
- High Learning Curve
- Matchmaking sometimes screws up pretty bad

THE UGLY
Diehard" fans of the original complaining about everything

BOTTOM LINE
If you like fast paced shooters or games like devil may cry

reviewText:
It's a cut above the rest of third-person shooters. Ability to wall-climb, dash around, and do some sick combos. It's like the Matrix, only with a sort of anime-like feel to it. The 6 characters they put in each have their own little way of playing, some that are super-effective against others. They also have 5 types of normal game modes, Deathmatch, Time Attack, Elimination, Gladiator, and Campaign. They also have a ranked mode, featuring the same modes as normal, just with a ranking system (duh :P) and you can only play with 3 other people, while in normal you play with 7 others. Campaign is the same, but you play with 3 others cooperatively against NPCs through a story-driven adventure.


My personal experience from playing this game has been phenomenal. It's really fun and gives me a chance to really break physics :D The people in the community are active and fun to play with (some are just grumpy :P) Either way, I'm sure you'll love the game as much as I do. Also, yes, Maiet's match-making system is pretty bad atm, but I'm sure later on, they'll put in their own servers.


I also love the soundtrack in this game. Love it <3
Now what are you still doing here? Get going and fight it out!

reviewText:
Really fast paced, redownloading for the second time after I got my laptop. Although I do dislike how some of it is pay to win and the items you buy expire, most people you find never use bought items. Also, the matchmaking system can ♥♥♥♥ someone off as you sometimes fight people with much more higher skill than you.

The campaign is extremely difficult, and you have to always be alert of any enemies spawning behind you, and use your ammo carefully, as the minibosses are full on tanks.

Most of the fighting is usually with guns, but the swords are extremely efficient, as you can just launch enemies up into the air and rekt them. Whether a newcomer or a pro, you will always enjoy this game.

If you're looking for a game that has fast paced action and a variety of playstyles, pick this up, it's free.

the costumes are pretty hot too

reviewText:
I feel upset that they removed the part of the game that really made it the awesome titan that it was. No Kstyle removes a good deal of the pace and removes a good deal of the skill ceiling of the game.

I was crazy into GunZ: The Duel. It was my favourite game for the longest time. From skirmishing with people, to just practicing new cancels for in game use. I could Double Butterfly, half-half-step and all of those fun things, and I wanted to learn Mstyle cancels.

The classes feel significantly stale and don't add any dimension to the play.

All in all, a really disappointed fan who would not recommend this new game to anyone who wasn't casual about it.

reviewText:
the game is good! but there are things that could be done that could fix some minor issues. first of all, the match making is non functional pitting  ppl who pick up a character fresh, agaisnt people who have put more than a few hours into theirs. it's hardly a fair match when it's like an ant vs an ant eater. gunslinger's grenade launcher should have less ammo preventing grenade spamming. barriers should be up around spawn points to keep from spawn camping,  which is a real big issue. spawn points should be a little more consistent to a fixed location, giving alot of leeway, like in the abandoned mansion, the spawn rooms on the second floor should be the fixed spawn point, and a barrier just beyond that corridor. barriers should keep hostile projectiles and damage out out to prevent cheaper spawn camps.

some of the characters could use a small boost in melee or given better functionality, and dashing should give half a second of invulnerability to make guns vs melee more interesting. and parrying should have only a second to 2 second cool down instead of requiring ZP allowing for more flowing skill based melee encounters. max's shield should be able to eat the regular combo but leave him vulnerable to the strong right click attack, in order to make him a more priority target, as well  as give him immunity to explosives so long as he's facing the grenade, making him useful agaisnt grenade happy people playing gunslinger

ofcourse these are just how i see the issues, and how they could be fixed, making characters more fun and viable against other characters, and make it easier on new beginners. still playing it in the hopes it'll get better.

and the server  forgetting your level should also be fixed.

reviewText:
It's hard to recommend a game if it's worth playing, but the pace of the game is nice and fast, but at times can be frustrating because of the lag between peers. Early access is what it is.

I've only played this a handful of times and can say with certainty that it is a decently fun game and somewhat enjoyable to an extent. The maps are diverse and the character abilities are so different between each character that it can help you try to bring a team together with those abilities in mind.

However, the amount of lag experienced in the game and the constant rubber banding of players is a hassle to deal with and the weird frame skips at parts. Even some people of the community take advantage of this and make it less enjoyable for players on both sides. Now on to the report function, from my experience if someone dislikes someone, as an example, carrying the team, they can report them for harassment/hacking/etc.

I don't know if there will be anyone looking at the in game logs, but excuses like that happen every so often it's getting really tiring. There's also the fact that the game is in early access and has its own set of bugs that need ironing. That won't stop the bickering however as some are hell bent on being the most 'opinionated' individul in the session.

It's not a bad game otherwise, just be mindful of the idiots that play.

reviewText: (PLEASE NOTE: This is technically not a review" of GunZ 2
date:
but more of an early impressions piece since the game is still in beta form. A follow up review will be made once the game is declared "finished" by MAIET.)

Full impressions: http://www.onrpg.com/articles/editorial/gunz2-steam-early-access-impressions/

After several years of waiting
recommended: MAIET Entertainment has finally released their high-action multiplayer shooter for (most of) the world to enjoy on Steam’s Early Access program. GunZ 2: The Second Duel is an online third person shooter about killing stuff with style. Players can run up walls
hoursPlayed: pull off acrobatic movements and switch between gunplay and melee combat on the fly. It's a sequel to the original GunZ: The Duel which came out back in 2003-2005.\n\nor those that do not know: One of the biggest changes in GunZ 2 compared to its predecessor is the removal of K-Style and D-style: Two popular play-styles that significantly changed the overall flow of gameplay by allowing players to jump
voteText: dash
helpfulPercent: block
votesHelpful: slash and shoot all at the same time. While this made the gameplay a lot more intense and exciting
votesTotal: it also brought weapon imbalance
votesFunny: made latency issues more apparent and even brought about health concerns from prolonged performance of these techniques
commentsCount: such as Carpal Tunnel.\n\nMAIET thought long and hard about wanting to bring "style play" back for the release of GunZ 2
column16: but came to the conclusion that it was too much of a hassle to bring it all back if they were going to achieve a more balanced shooting game.\n\nWith my extensive time spent playing the South Korean
column17: Europe and Taiwan versions of the game (as if I couldn’t get enough of this game in my life…)
column18: it was now time for me to jump head first into the Steam Early Access for North America
column19: just to see if there has been any significant changes made
column20:
as well as being able to play against others in my region of world.

---

First bit of disappointment that I had with the Steam version was that MAIET still has not included any initial character customization when selecting between the four available classes
column21: which for some reason all have names attached to them unlike before. The Silent Avenger is now called Ivan
column22: the Gunslinger is called Elena
column23: the Shield Trooper’s name is Max and the newest class
column24: the Shadow Dancer
column25: is named Rena. Between these four classes
column26: they each have many different strengths and weaknesses
column27: but you still cannot select different hair styles or faces for them
column28: unlike the original GunZ.\n\nIn the original GunZ: The Duel: Instead of different classes
column29: players had access to a weight system
column30: where they could select any weapon they wanted just as long as the player had enough weight space available to hold them all
column31: and this was all dictated by the armor each character wore
column32: so if a player had good armor
column33: they could carry multiple weapons or heavier weapons. However
column34: this proved to give a false sense of customization in the later levels due to the use of K/D-style limiting most loadout options.\n\nOnce I selected my character
column35: I went through the tutorial which hasn’t changed very much since the EU and TW versions. After completion
column36: one noticeable change was the inclusion of crystals and ores which can be earned from unlocking achievements
column37: opening supply crates every hour and from dismantling equipment. These ores and crystals can be used to earn weapons and equipment from the tesla machine
column38: which is basically a fancy gachapon system. And as much as I dislike gambling systems
column39: the tesla machine is actually very fair in comparison to other gachapon systems
column40: mainly because it actually shows a global number of chances to win each available prize. Once you understand how the tesla machine works
column41: it’s quite possible to wait patiently for the prize list to drop as low as possible to increase your chances of getting the main prizes
column42: which are usually permanent weapons or special costumes.\n\nThe three modes that are currently available in GunZ 2 include Team Deathmatch
column43: Team Elimination and Time Assault:  While Team Deathmatch is fairly self-explanatory; Team Elimination is similar to Team Deathmatch except that players have one life per round. If you die during a match
column44: you cannot respawn. Think of it like a typical round of Counter-Strike with bombing run or hostage capture mode
column45: except that there’s no main objective other than defeating the enemy team… and that people can jump around the environment like something out of a Cirque du Soleil show.\n\nThe other available game mode is Time Assault
column46: which is very much a straight forward Attack & Defend game mode where one team defends one of three target points on the map while the other team tries to destroy those targets. This mode and Team Elimination mode is where the gameplay truly starts to shine
column47: as teamwork plays a big role here. Of course
column48: it’s hard to engage in teamwork when the thought of trying to be a nonstop
column50: one-man army kind of action hero is so tempting
column51: but it usually pays off.\n\nAs to whether or not GunZ 2 takes skill to play compared to its predecessor
column52: I would answer that by saying: It’s debatable. Gameplay is now more focused on team play rather than solo performance
column53: although it is still very possible to hold your own in solo situations
column54: no matter which class you choose. As I’ve seen time and time again where players have been able to carry entire teams on their backs or have been able to clutch it out during a 1-on-4 situation during a team elimination match. These intense moments really show that quick wits are now what GunZ 2 is all about
column55: rather than repetitious muscle memory and a shallow overarching strategy of “spot an enemy and K/D-style them as hard as you can.”\n\nPersonally speaking: After a few matches in normal mode
column56: and having the opportunity of playing with people in my region
column57: I would have to say that Gunz 2 is actually more difficult to play than Gunz 1. Without the crutch of insanely high mobility
column58: I was forced to make decisions more quickly. I found myself dying a lot in Gunz 2 because of the difficulty of adjusting to the more team-based and snap decision making nature of gameplay. Some battles do get pretty mindless (especially up against grenade spamming Elena players and YOLO flamethrowin' Max players)
column59: but usually when you’re up against a full premade group
column60: you really need to focus.\n\nThe biggest issue with the Steam version of GunZ 2 is most definitely the lag issues. It seems like MAIET didn’t get the memo that peer-to-peer connections do not work well in online video games outside of South Korea
column61: since not every country out there is the size of a small state
column62: and not everyone has access to T1+ internet connection speeds. Unlike most modern shooting games that use dedicated servers
column63: GunZ 2 randomly assigns one player as the “host” before a match begins
column64: which means that if the host lags
column65: everyone lags. And even if the host has a decent connection
column66: they will still have a major advantage over enemy players due to hitscan detection and registration time. If a player is not selected as the host
column67: they will need to lead their shots constantly; otherwise they’ll be missing a lot of hits. This is especially noticeable when using Ivan’s sniper rifle
column68: where it can take up to half a second or more for a shot to travel from point A to point B
column69: and by the time the shot travels across the map
column70: a target would have already moved from their position.\n\nOverall
column72: it shows a lot of promise. Even with the direct removal of K/D-style
column73: it still managed to give me the same thrill and excitement that the original GunZ gave me. If they can manage to develop some kind of netcode that can compensate for the latency issues before adding new content
column74: then I could see GunZ 2 having quite a long life span."

reviewText:
If you were expecting this game (GunZ 2) to be similar to GunZ, then unfortunately you will be disappointed. :( Timing on the game seems off compared to the first, match making can be unbalanced rank wise, and it's so hard to figure out how things work and what things do in the game. For example, I didn't know i could buy stuff from the Tesla store, and when you do buy something from the store you can only use it for a limited time (1 day to an hour). Which I kind of find as pretty stupid.

Then again, I was expecting a lot more from this game, so I potentionally set myself up for disappointment. :P

PROS: Nostalgia, new special attacks,
CONS: Limited time items you buy from store, can't look for servers, can only create/use one character for free,

reviewText:
Being an Early Access title and Bugs and glitches will be around, this game plays great!

I first played GunZ The Duel many years ago with my friends after school where we would face off for hours on end.
This game although different hold onto the the feeling of playing a GunZ game where the action is fun to both watch and to play. The combat is a dizzying mixture of The Matrix(Complete with Swords and Wall running) and CS, It is played in a third Person POV which feels needed with all that can be occuring on screen and the available cosmetic armour pieces to make your character really your own.

Finding games is fast and easier than it was in GunZ 1 You Que up for what you want to play Solo or with friends and the system finds opponents for you. This is a departure from GunZ 1 which was organized y channels and a Lobby" system where you can browse through all the games currently taking place and join in there. Seeing as it is my only point of reference to any game that comes even remotly close to this game for Action based Shooting goes. One thing from the original that is not present here is the K-Style which was just an interesting combination of exploits animation cancel bugs and glitches. It will take those who are used to that some time to adapt to the new style of play but it is worth your time to do so.

I have logged 15.8 hours on this game while working each day and i am loving every moment i spend on it.
A worthwhile grab for any old GunZ Vet looking to make some heads roll and for te person who maybe never touched the Original title.  Once you get pasted the learning curve you will find hours of fun in TDM Team Elimination and A&D Maps with more modes to come!

I CANNOT wait to see what the future has in store for GunZ 2 bu you can expect me to be there waiting Katana in hand awaiting my next Trial by fire.

-Blyte"

reviewText:
I'm writing this review while the game is still in beta.
Let me start off with, if you liked Gunz1 and played it religiously you'll probably dislike this game.  Everything is much more restricted" in this game.  Your choice of character design for the most part doesn't exsist.  Skills like aerial recovery(which at the time of writing doiesn't work btw) or wake-up attacks are now tied to a meter.  Instead of "styles" you're given a skill tree which you have to unlock by levels to even get were once basic skills such as aerial recovery.  Every class has a skill from the get go that is basicly an instant kill.  Lag is rampent due to the p2p structure and net code they use.  Oh and instead of their being a lobby with a selection of games you're auto matched into a game LoL style.
