reviewText:
the game is good! but there are things that could be done that could fix some minor issues. first of all, the match making is non functional pitting  ppl who pick up a character fresh, agaisnt people who have put more than a few hours into theirs. it's hardly a fair match when it's like an ant vs an ant eater. gunslinger's grenade launcher should have less ammo preventing grenade spamming. barriers should be up around spawn points to keep from spawn camping,  which is a real big issue. spawn points should be a little more consistent to a fixed location, giving alot of leeway, like in the abandoned mansion, the spawn rooms on the second floor should be the fixed spawn point, and a barrier just beyond that corridor. barriers should keep hostile projectiles and damage out out to prevent cheaper spawn camps.

some of the characters could use a small boost in melee or given better functionality, and dashing should give half a second of invulnerability to make guns vs melee more interesting. and parrying should have only a second to 2 second cool down instead of requiring ZP allowing for more flowing skill based melee encounters. max's shield should be able to eat the regular combo but leave him vulnerable to the strong right click attack, in order to make him a more priority target, as well  as give him immunity to explosives so long as he's facing the grenade, making him useful agaisnt grenade happy people playing gunslinger

ofcourse these are just how i see the issues, and how they could be fixed, making characters more fun and viable against other characters, and make it easier on new beginners. still playing it in the hopes it'll get better.

and the server  forgetting your level should also be fixed.

reviewText: The game is incredibly broken. No dedicated servers (players host, it breaks the game a lot), broken weapons (Reapers especially), aim bots, zoom macros (sniper rifles), unbalanced classes (Play Ivan to win, play Rose for a challenge), a weird leveling system (you don't unlock gameplay essential things until later levels but you can't level because there's not enough new people coming in), a loosely veiled pay-to-win weapon acquisition system, and a very elite playerbase who refuse to acknowledge problems. The campaign is fun... if the game were made in 1998 (coins for respawn? Really? You don't even get anything from campaign except experience). If you're looking for a decent free arena shooter to play with friends, give it a shot. If you can find a fair match you'll have fun going head to head. But if you get into a match against four Ivans with Reaper sniper rifles who shoot you dead before you can even move, you'll snap your mouse in half before you waste any more time on this game. Give it a shot and figure it out on your own but don't expect something anything if you've got no one to play with you.

reviewText:
Positives: The animations, graphic style, and general look of the game has significantly improved to be much more aesthetically pleasing.
There is a new array of weapons.
The Q E skill system is very smooth.
Both gunplay and swordplay is smooth, but  melee combat falls off because once you've been hit you're stuck in a combo.

Negatives: Dashing feels clunky as there is now a cooldown before you can dash again.
Wallrunning is clunky, and has taken away the freedom of movement that GunZ had as you cannot quickly dismount the wall.
Vertical wallrunning has become a pain in the ♥♥♥.
The class system is bad. The game should really just have a standard male/female character with more customization.
THE BIGGEST ISSUE is that this game is no longer skill based. The game has turned into a contest of who can melee the other one down the ground and finish them with an SMG first.
THE SECOND BIGGEST ISSUE is that once you've been struck by a melee attack, you're stuck in the combo until you get knocked down and shot with an SMG.

It's really quite displeasing that there's no real way to block once you've been hit.

While although this game is a slight letdown to anyone who has played the first GunZ game, it's still relatively fun. Since it's not a complete game I can only hope that the Devs listen to the community and bring back a playstyle that is based on skill and reactions.

reviewText:
One of those stereotypical Korean games, it's a sequel to the old carpal-tunnel-inducing game GunZ: The Duel. Whereas GunZ: The Duel was fast-paced gunkata action that would wreck your wrists and fingers permanently, GunZ 2: The Second Duel is a slower game that focuses on player classes instead of allowing everyone to customize their characters and kit them out with whatever weapon they liked the most. This is both good AND bad.

The Good: Every character has their particular quirks that makes them great against some and weaker against everyone else. Each character comes with a particular set of skills; passives and extra movement options are unlocked as levels are earned. You can feasibly unlock every character and level them up individually, but that's tedious and boring. You're better off finding the one character you click with and sticking with them through your journey into the disappointment that is GunZ 2: The Second Duel.

The Bad: Everything else. The game has HORRIFIC netcode. I mean, I had not thought it was possible to beat old early 90's FPS netcode meant for 56K modems, but GunZ 2: The Second Duel proves that they achieved what they'd set out to do. Expect to see enemies warping around the map, and dying to enemies you can't even see on a regular basis. The only time these problems are alleviated are if you are the game's host; then, your ping is non-existent and you pretty much win the game if you're even slightly competent.

The Ugly: It's a free-to-play game, so it attracts the worst kinds of people the internet has to offer. The game insists on upgrading your weapons, but there's ALMOST NO DISCERNIBLE DIFFERENCE between the weapons statistically, and some of the weapons you can upgrade to EVEN WITH USING REAL MONEY have LITTLE TO NO IMPACT on the game whatsoever, and some are even WORSE THAN YOUR BASE WEAPONRY. Admirable, but no-one cares what kind of flashy weapon or skin you're using, 'cause 90% of the time people aren't even looking at you. Similarly hilarious, some of the miscellaneous items for sale - such as a hat that looks like a cat cutely perching on your head, ready to pounce - are EXORBITANTLY expensive for a F2P game.

Honestly, steer well clear of this game. If you're even slightly interested in the game, at least wait for them to fix the netcode before playing, else you'll walk out of the game wishing you'd listened to me.

reviewText:
Turns into a patience game if you're not in NA (and maybe EU? idk). It region locks you so you can't change to a region with more people.

From the 2.2 hours on record i've spent like 5 min in the tutorial, 15 min in a match (that didn't go that well), and the rest just waiting for it to find a match.

The single normal match I had was laggy as hell with some players teleporting everywhere. Also... the fps on anything above low settings becomes a handicap specially for this type of game (my computer runs other high requirement games just fine).

I know the game is on early access and improvements will come, but as for now I can't really recommend it.

reviewText:
Being a GunZ 1 player on and off for several years I couldn't wait to try GunZ 2. So, when the Beta finally opened for NA... well... I had to wait a few more days.
After the standard launch issues cleared up, I jumped in to see if it would live up to the hype.

First off I was disappointed to see that they had removed customization in favor of four preset classes.



Ivan wields a sniper rifle, katana, and SMG.
Rena duel swords, duel pistols, and SMG.
Elena a baseball bat, assault rifle, and nade launcher.
Max is equipped with a riot shield, mini gun, and flame thrower.

Each character does have a few sets of clothing and weapons to purchase, but it's cosmetic and slight stat variations. At least it means nothing is pay to win at the moment.
The shop does sell a few cosmetic items for real money at the moment.($15 for a hat!)

I picked Ivan and moved on to the lobby, which is your standard shooter lobby other than that(for the moment) there doesn't seem to be a way to select the room you join. You can queue up for 1-3 types of PvP.

-Team Death Match
-Team Elimination- Kill the entire enemy team. First to 5 wins.
-Time Assault- Destroy the enemy teams object within a set time.

or you can do the Co-op campaign.
I picked PvP.

So, now we can talk about combat.
In GunZ 1 I despised K-Style because of how it was implemented. It was basically a glitch that the developers didn't bother to fix. For GunZ 2 I was hoping for a more refined combat system. Something fast and elegant. Something that could match the good parts of K-style and remove the bad.
So did GunZ 2 deliver?

Well, it can be fast. Really fast. Not just movement but TTK is really low. If you get caught in a combo, you're stun-locked and dead.

I personally miss the epic battles from GunZ 1. Two equally skilled players could fight back and forth for minutes.

In GunZ 2 that's replaced by a lot mindless spamming. Blocking is made almost useless by special abilities that characters gain as the level up, meaning that combat in GunZ 2 is roughly the equivalent of Call of Duty with swords.

Despite the disappointment from the combat system, I decided to give the campaign a try. Surprisingly where the games shines. They're actually MMO instance quality missions. There are lots of waves but the require awareness, positioning, weapon and ability management to clear.
Bosses can feature multiple stages and well scripted abilities that require a bit of thought to counter.

I haven't finished the campaign yet but so far it's fun. The downside is there doesn't seem to be any form of reward. I have yet to get a shinny new gun or even a dirty sock. Cash gains from it are also slow in comparison to the PvP modes.

Overall, it's a fun game despite the fact the combat is frustratingly lacking of depth. I really hope they refine it a bit more and try to get a little closer to what I liked about GunZ 1 rather than a third person version of Team Fortress 2. Still, It's free the campaign is pretty cool. Give it a try.

reviewText:
(NOTE: THIS REVIEW WAS BASED UPON AN EARLY ACCESS VERSION OF THE GAME. IT MAY NOT BE APPLICABLE TO THE CURRENT GAME VERSION, WHICH HAS BEEN NOW OFFICIALLY RELEASED. THIS REVIEW MAY BE EDITED LATER ON TO SUIT THE NEW GAME VERSION. FOR THE MOMENT, READER DISCRETION ON HOW FAR TO TAKE THIS REVIEW IS ADVISED.)
Feels fun, but has many flaws.
Bad netcode, player hosting instead of server hosting, weapons cost more than characters (which there are only four of, 2 are much to simlar... oh, and you have to BUY characters!), revives cost money and are slow to come back for campaign, no solo mode of any kind, hackers, community isn't that great, several things need balancing, etc etc.
However, this game IS in Beta, so hopefully they'll fix it.
You can try playing and be patient with it, to give it support, but if you want something great, hold off on it until they fix it. It most definately has the potential to better itself, and MAIET is working quite hard to make that so.

reviewText:
There seem to be a lot of negative reviews of this game, so let me put in my two cents.

When I first saw this game in the steam store it looked like a wallrunning ninja tps hybrid. And when I downloaded and played it, that is exactly what I received.
I was also pleasantly surprised by the 4player Co-op option and the the campaign doesn't start off fantastic I hear it gets fairly good, and playing with three friends always makes things more fun.
The game also has pay to win and MMO elements;
MMO elements like friends lists, PMs, and the option to make a clan, add something nice to the game.
I found the pay to win"esque nature of the game wasn't a deal breaker for me
date: because it's more like "pay to advance faster". Without paying a single cent you can exceed at the game by skill alone easily.\n\nThe other thing is game progression
recommended: meaning players who have spent longer on the game will have better gear than you
hoursPlayed: and a few extra abilities.\nHowever
voteText: this does not put them at an extreme advantage
helpfulPercent: and is balanced nicely.\nOn my first game I was able to get a nice amount of frags even though I was a beginner.\nIn terms of gear
votesHelpful: the best gear is only slightly better than the defalut stuff
votesTotal: with upgrades being slight. This means that no matter what
votesFunny: you still need skill to win
commentsCount: not money. A player with the best gear will still easily be poned by a more skilled player.\n\nI think this game s a lot of fun because of the ninja like elements to it with the wall running
column16: the variance in the classes
column17: and because of a lot of the unique gameplay aspects in it. Being able to switch weapons quickly means that a lot of the time you will be most efficient in using your entire aresenal agains an opponent
column18: like switching from close range to mid range quickly to retreat from a flamethrower
column19: or as a sniper dashing back quickly from an approaching assailant with a sword
column20: to then quickly pull out your own sword and dash forward to catch them off guard. I like that you can use weapons while dashing and wallrunning
column21: meaning I can dash sideways to avoid a sniper
column22: and then quickly run across the wall towards him firing my SMG while jumping from wall to wall to avoid his fire
column23: then dash to the side onto a pillar
column24: then change to my sword while running in a spiral around that pillar so he can't keep track of me
column25: then dash behind him and finish him off with the sword.\n\nThere are breast physics as some have so crudely fixated on
column26: but unless you are swinging around character models in the lobby
column27: they don't distract from gameplay. Also when characters with skirts die sometimes
column28: they ragdoll into some compromising positions
column30: it's easy to either ingore or fixate on
column31: depending on your attittude.\n\nSo in short

reviewText:
Let me begin first by saying this game is new and I've put my share of time into playing a character to level cap.

This game is definitely worth a try being free and to add it's one of those games where you don't have to sit down and play it all day to get anywhere. There are a few glaring technical issues that still linger in the back but as far as actual gameplay goes, the gameplay is very fluid fast paced.  If you are a returning player to Gunz and expect to K-Style (I mean take advantage of unintended mechanics in the game in an attempt to denote yourself as a skillworthy player) all over the place, I've got news for you buddy: you won't be.

Recommended for those who enjoy a mix of shoot 'em up and hack and slash.

reviewText:
What i like:
-Visually appealing
-Nice map designs
-Feels like the Gunz we all know - fast paced combat
-Classes are ACTUALLY classes now
-Sleek user interface

What i don't Like :
- Rena is a pointless class/hero whatever you want to call it
.... you give Ivan an extremely deadly sniper that u can zoom in with and that has no recoil what so ever to ivan and call him asassin of sorts... ok well that seems legit , now why don't you give Rena something that packs a punch for example a shotgun instead of a minigun that is pretty bad compared to guns that other classes have.... All the other classes seem pretty balanced... like Max is very good close range , Ivan long range and Elena mid range.... but Rena just seems to be like a cross between them all and is not really great at anything... i had hard time earning exp on Rena really.... on Invan i'd go like 12:6:X 20:X:X and just level up early on from 1 game you know why ? cuz of his long range pewpew... And no im not talking right now about skill... im talking about the Mechanics of guns ofc( just my opinion ) anyway to shorten this - all classes seem well rounded except Rena.

(EDIT): maybe  make her pistols more precise  or instead of this pretty useless burst fire mode on pistols give her kinda like a sniping" mode to increase accuracy on her shots well.. okay maybe leave the burst fire mode for high mag pistols but like i bought the pistols that do more dmg has smaller fire rate and less ammo in a mag so burst fire is pretty useless cuz i lose all my ammo in an instant and dont really do much... so maybe make some sorts of other pistols that are for sniping at mid/high range ? that'd make people have a choice between fast fire rate or high dmg output. make her a mid-range sniper of sorts... just something so she doesn't feel as "allover the place" when it comes to a role

cuz let's be honest - Ivan has a zoom that helps him ( doesn't increase recoil or decrease accuracy... why give Rena a burst fire mode that decreases her movement speed ? like really ? doesn't it seem weird to you ? yeah it seems to give you a little less recoil but not really that much to make it reliable... i personally haen't found it useful in fights at all... unless you get to somehow stand still somewhere people can't see you in mid/low range to use it... which usually doesn't happen.

-Not enough video option control - when i enable a single option in Advanced options tab it DRASTICALLY reduces the fps... how about giving some more options if that's possible ? also some brightness slider would be nice

-Restrictions on Swords... why does Rena Strictly have to have 2 swords and Ivan 1 Sword... i get the thought process behind making guns class specific but why melee weapons ?  it's nice to make some restrictions but imo too much is not good either.

-No advanced Movement mechanics... yes yes i know blaa blaa Gunz 1 broken.. stuff.. stuff noobs are noobs
recommended:
stuff stuff.... but really... im not talking here about the HUGE bugs like Reload shot or dagger lunge bug thing ( forgot how its called ) but simples ones really that made it more fun and the movements more varied to trick your enemy etc.

wall slash-climbing - when you hit the wall to jump again and go up the wall.

Maybe some kind of a dash cancel maybe not quiet butterfly step-ish but something that would let you to cancel your dash in mid air or maybe just make the gap between dashes shorter.. you know what i mean
hoursPlayed:
... like something not as straight forward... the dashing is really now just 4 direction 1 dash a seconds or smthn...

-no replay function... one thing that should be there. Gunz 1 had it why not implement it in Gunz 2 ? it's not like it was a bug or anything.. just a convenient tool.


- no changeable crosshair ( size
voteText: shape etc )\n\nanyway i hope that made sense

reviewText:
I played the original Gunz, waaaay back in the dark ages of F2P games. It was one of the best experiences of my gaming life. Met people, joined a clan, reeeeally got into mid-pvping (thou never was good enough to get even near the top 500 xD) and had a good time just being part of a game that was actually not too bad, for what it was.

Now after saying that, Gunz 2... is nothing like the original, besides the name. Yes the combats similiar, but the limited choice of equipment without buying extra characters can be annoying. Pvp is full of the predictable hackers (F2P, watcha expect right) that just never seem to get taken care of after numious reports, and Co-op is just.. generally bad for new and casual gamers. Seriously, the price tag for the coins you need to revive in that mode is $2.50 American Dollars.. that is actual money you got to put into this game just to revive one time. One. Time. Can anyone else say giant rip-off?

Do I recommand this game? Only if you go in, not expecting more than you normally should in a F2P. It has its perks, and if you get heavily enough into it, ya, I can see why theres a community at least attempting to go around the company trying to make it pay to win.

Just.. don't try to make water into beer here. At least you don't got to pay a dime into it to enjoy casual games with a select group of friends, and having a good time dueling :)

reviewText: Now, i can tell what alot of you are thinking, well at least the from a viewpoint of a person who was a huge fan of the very first Gunz The Duel, as i imagine a fair amount of the people playing or who looked foward to playing this may have been, but. Gunz the Second duel is a huge dissapointment. I came willingly with my money ready and my memories of the hack and slash fun times i use to have (when there weren't hackers all over it) i was brimming with excitement when i saw this hit the steam store and was playing it immediatley, but what i thought would have been a smoother re-vamped super shiny new content filled game... turned out to be one of the worst experiences i have ever had with an online game. Sure while i write this review the game is in open beta but it doesn't even feel ready for that it is clunky, laggy, choppy, buggy, the game feels like it is still in pre alpha and should not be played yet. My first experience with this game was myself and my brother jumping into the single player campaign  thinking oh sweet some fun co-op to play beside the main multiplayer side of it, but what we got was a bunch of hallways and corridors filled with enemies that could so easily destroy you the second you take a wrong step careful not to get hit once or the enemies stun lock you and kill you almost imediatley. They also have the nerver to add  in a life system with COINS as your life you start the day with 3 coins you can use to revive yourself and fallen allies if you lose all 3 of them back to the start you go with nothing gained, making it super hard to enjoy it with just a friend. they then basically force you to buy revival coins to continue playing the single player side of the story when it's not lagging that is, and don't even think of playing it alone there isn't a hope in hell of playing through it unless your willing to pour money into the game. Now the multiplayer... OH BOY.. THE MULTIPLAYER... there is nothing good to be said about it it's CLUNKY, IT'S GLITCHY, and from my experience so far so laggy that your enemy if they are the host will have killed you before you have even seen them appear, you simply die while seeing these bodies of the other players jumping around the room at 1 frame a second. And the classes are NOT BALANCED AT ALL. Swordplay is almost useless in this game the only thing it's good for is it's knock up ability and even then once they are knocked up they can't be hit again unless you switch over to your gun and shoot at there stunned body on the floor. and the servers are terrible. This is not gunz this is not fun if your thinking this will be just like the first game don't even bother this is not worth your time give it a year or two then look back into it maybe they might have a working game, and a non-linear unbalanced story, MAYBE!!! they might not use every asset they have to extort the player base into spending money to play the damn game... i give GUNZ THE SECOND DUEL a 3/10 for at least giving me a look at what could have been a sequel.

reviewText:
Taking away the ability to mix and match your own weapons is one of the BIGGEST mistakes they could have made. Now they have this lame certain gender only character class system that lets you only use certain weapons. BIG DISSAPOINTMENT. Instead of locking the weapons to specific characters they should have just made each character have different stats and maybe some different abilities with Pros and Cons to each character (i.e. The big tank dude would have more health than other characters but be alot slower in the movement area.) another feature to help balance it out would be that some weapons will have different affects on some characters (i.e. If a smaller character used the gatling gun it would slow down her movement speed a little, big guy used lighter weapons it would not be able to aim as well cause of his big muscles( I cant really think of a downside to this at the moment)). It seems that game developers wasted their time making up these characters when they could have focused more on gamplay and customization.

With that said the combat system has improved and without that ridiculous butterfly technique in the first game, Gunz 2 is alot more nooby friendly. Adding the special moves and passives help make your character a little more unique. The Story missions is a nice change of pace and gives you something else to do other than pvp.

Overall its about an average game that can be fun for awhile and would have been better if you had the ability to mix and match weapons.

reviewText:
Play this game first. The biggest problem that people have with this game is that they never play it long enough. Until you get at least 100 hours, you don't know what you're talking about.
The game is a lot different from when you first play it to when you have learned how to play it.

0/10 no sdk, no anti-lead, barely any customization

Some people like some games, others don't.
Reviews are never solid.
Try this game for yourself and come up with your own opinion, that is the only way to get an accurate review for yourself.

This is what I think Maiet should have done:
• Add weapons, maps, characters
• Add patches when you add weapons, maps, characters
***• KEPT IT LIKE THE KOREAN BETA, EVERYTHING LOOKED FINE BACK THEN
even early access was better than today's GunZ 2

After a substantial amount of time with this, I don't like how this game feels.
Let me give you a few reasons why:

I: The feeling of the game

1) Dashing, as useful as it is, it doesn't flow as well as GunZ 1, though MAIET makes it a point to    make this sequel very different from GunZ 1, the only way to keep your speed is to keep dashing.
The only way to make dash work is to make things a bit more complicated, not too much.
Integrate it with double dashing, dash jump dash

2) Wall climbing
It's inconsistent. I'm not trying to ring in anyone's ear about GunZ 1, but it has the same problem as    dashing does. You can't go up at a constant rate. When you are at the top end of your wallrun    upwards, you completely stop until it finally reads that you've pressed the spacebar again. It takes    too long to get anywhere.

3) Stunlock
They should have thrown this out altogether. You can't guard against it and you are at the mercy of    your attacker. It is one of the main reasons why this game feels awkward and why melee is ruined.

4) Melee
One of the most broken pieces of the game. Why on earth is every hit a stunlock? Why am I    playing 3D super smash bros? I understand Maiet's part in trying to make this game more    strategic, but he just recreated another way of playing the game chicken". I would much rather    prefer stunlock until your target finds a way out of it. Max is a fine example of that
date:
a good melee    stunlock until his opponent finally turns around and blocks.
No counter attacks besides parry? Really? That's really boring.

****************************************
All of the melee weapons do the EXACT SAME THING
hoursPlayed: then eventually knock you    down
voteText: if you got rid of the sounds and models
helpfulPercent:
you couldn't tell who is using what

The daggers don't have a lunge (Rena's R doesn't count)
The sword and blunt weapon and daggers and shield ALL can flip
EVEN Wayne's whip can flip
****************************************
II. Weapons

1) Accuracy
The accuracy of automatic weapons (and Wayne's pistol) are just horrible.
Though thirdperson may distort your depth perception to make everything smaller
votesHelpful: it shouldn't make    your gun shoot in the same cone shape a shotgun's spread has.\nIt is far too inconsistent and there really isn't that much to compensate for it
votesTotal: it is a completely    random circle that the bullets decide to go to.\nI understand that they don't want people to die in an instant from any distance but the Coffin and    Striker are just unusable at mid range.\nSure
votesFunny:
they are supposed to be close range weapons since they are SMGs but being close range    just makes you vulnerable to melee attacks.

2) Variety
There is no variety here
commentsCount: another thing that irritates me. Each class is limited to 2 different    weapons
column16:
and you cannot have 2 of the same or one that belongs to a different class (With the    exception for Ivan and Rena's SMGs). No standard revolvers or pistols for anyone to share.

3) Tesla shop
I don't feel I need to explain this
Trying to get premium items without money?
Good luck.

III. Customizability

1) Characters
They come with preset clothes? And they HAVE to buy them with 15000 gold?
Sure gold is easy to come by
column17:
but you can't by clothes for every class
after already using 15000 for each individual weapon

2) Weapons
I liked the level weapons from GunZ 1 only because there was a huge array of options
Though
column18: I appreciate being able to buy anything no matter what level I am
column19:
there are very little    options to choose from.

3) Maps
The maps are okay
column20: but I wish they'd make a replica of Dungeon from GunZ 1\nThe new maps are not okay
column21:
they just rip them from the campaign levels and call it a day (with the    exception of the hunter training course)

reviewText: Ok so my friend challenges me to a game of gunz and suggests Gunz 2 as an alternative since it came onto steam. First thing we look for is a practice mode and a private match mode. Both of which are missing. This is a troubling begginning since the first gunz was all about skill and what is that without a method of practice? I start looking through the inventory and shop and such to see if there are any minor improvements or otherwise that I could make. Yet again I am sorely dissappointed by the addition of some for of RPG like stats for random crits etc. These are not for a shooter which is what I remember gunz to be. Next we have the clan set up. We started one up before even getting into first match which is good for accessability however inviting people from the clan menu does not work. Invite from friends menu worked. Let's try clicking our game mode. Oh...it kicked my teammate...Oh...now it won't let me reinvite him. Relog. Works again. Try out campaign time because the PvP is looking very far out of the question right now. Get in game> Try dashing.....well....that was uneventful. Try chaining dashes>...Oh...doesn't do anything. Try wall running> Very clunky...kinda slow... Ok so they firmly destroyed the games mobility aspect. Let's try some combat. Slash>Block Nope, animation is too clunky for that. Oh hey right click jumps higher than space bar. Maybe I can use that with dash! Nope disappointed it again. Weapon swap works well!...Oh look at that...There's no way to really defend as a melee specialist. The only thing they had before was mobility and that is very...lax...If you are looking for the original gunz play style you are going to be sorely disappointed. Sorry Maiet...I had major suspicions when Raiderz" was announced as a trial of the engine before Gunz 2 came out but this surely affirms all the failures I foresaw.\n\nTL;DR: It plays with the mobility of TERA and has the nerve to call the game a sequal to Gunz"

reviewText:
Although this game is somewhat different from the original I feel that it's a very solid game. The combat flows nicely, there is some decent customization, and everything has had a graphical upgrade. There are 4 characters that play drastically different depending on one's play style, all of which are very balanced (despite most people saying they aren't). All of the characters also have there own arsenal of weapons and skills which adds some depth and progression to the game. This game is skill/knowledge based which makes it extremely fun and gives it a reasonable learning curve. The skill is mainly dodging and gunplay while the knowledge is how to counter certain characters/playstyles. The game also has a decent story through The Campaign Mode which is also fun and challenging. They currently only have one campaign but by the looks of it they plan to add more along with some challenge modes (which I am looking forward to).

However, there are 3 minor issues that I have had with the game which I pressume are being worked on. The first problem I have is lack of PvP game modes. There are currently 3 (being Team Deathmatch, Team Elimination, and Time Assualt) all of which are very basic (i.e. Kill enemy team). The Second problem I have is lack of map variety. There are currently 7 maps most of which, although funtional and good looking, are very bland in design. Basically all maps have 3 ways to get to the same area which makes maps seem very small (I assume this is to keep up the hectic and fast paced action of the game). My final issue I have with this game are the coins for the Campaign. The coins are extra lives for when you die and you only get 3 a day, which dont get me wrong is more generous than most games, but I think the vast majority of people would have prefered 3 per level or checkpoint revives.

Overall I find this game enjoyable but, slighty lacking in variety. I would reccomend this to any fan of the original Gunz, or someone looking for fast paced enjoyable gun combat.
voteText: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I've been playing this game for a while and I can say it's definetely fun, thought there are some bad points I'm going to point out right away.
- Max , this class feels a bit strange in a game where mobility is key. (he can't move much while shooting and is an easy target), it's also frustrating that he gets immunity to knock back from mellee weapons when shooting but I guess it makes him somewhat powerful, though Ivan can easylly HS 1 hit him.
- Bugs I've encountered so far (often): At the end of 25% of my games, I 've had to close the game by pressing alt+f4 in order to reopen and go back in lobby, losing my crates. If you chat in team chat right before entering a game in the lobby the game closes and you get hell banned for 14 minutes from getting in another pvp game (red card).
- Options that should be implemeneted to facilitate the UI : A leave group button when in a party.
- Options that may cater to other players: Practice mode, Custom games, A game lobby (you can still implement the quick start button), Voting to change hosts (some laggy hosts don't know a lick of english for some reason)

Aside from whats mentionned above, the game is amazing in it's current state, I do not mind the removal of butterfly, which was, as mentionned in alot of previous statements, a bug. The class system is nice, but alot of old gen players hate it, maybe it would be better to have a character creator where you could make you're own character, chose skills and use any weapons (like in gunz 1, but way more elaborate). The class system in this game has been done before , people look for innovation, not copy paste.

Anyway, I do not mind the class system, I love the fact that it takes no time to get to level 20 as well. The current cash related model is fine and not p2w which is great. It'd be cool if crystals were a bit easyer to get since it' incredibly hard to get anything good from the tesla shop.

Aside from all mentionned above, Gunz 2 is a fun fast paced mmofps that I love and hope will grow into something better. If anyone reading this is new, Rena is 50k gold, so start with her to avoid whining about that later on. See you in the mansion (most probable map)

reviewText:
Early-Access Review: I have History with Gunz1 and 45+ hour with Gunz2 now. So let face it. this is beta! you cant ask for a Full game in beta- Beta means there will be bug's (and heck their not noticeable after the last few update's). So im here to explain the downside's of current beta. the diffreance of Gunz1 & 2 and what old gunz1 viet might be missing and soon love.

The current major downside is trying to get into the game. you need to restart the game about 4-6 time's to get into the full server"

un-noticeable learning curve for wall running/ fighting that old K-styler might enjoy. The gun system is little wacky at time's and there definitely some OP combo's at lower tier's (level15 bellow).

if you just started the game. worry about leveling up a char to lv10+. heck lv20. save your money for those nifty screw thing's like +hp
date:
+Def. lv10 you get 1. lv20 you got 5. then take those screw and upgrade em. IT WILL FAIL UPGRADE'S. but you will get end results of ALOT more armor and HP or w/e one you pick and you just end up owning everyone cuz they don't know about the screw upgrading (do it alot ;p )


So whats change from Gunz1 in Gunz2?
1.No K-style.

2.No over powered items that you need to use real money to buy from Shop/lotto.

3.New leveling system. what can be a big change for some people but it has it's up's and down's.

4.Character system with set 3 weapons.

-Currently 4 character's to pick from- more will come out later
-This looks to be inplaced into the game so that not everyone useing the "sword+shootgun" only set. and let's face it Gunz1 everyone used a sword+shootgun. From my understanding they will be adding more guns later so there were not all stuck with the same 3 weapon's.

5.Old gunz1 maps are still around in gunz2 (there still being added)

6.Quickly enter game's with the new lobbying system.

7. Freestyle wallrunning (and OMG once you get the hang of it
recommended:
it's way nicer then then old K-style wall runing(im not one for the glitchy looking wall run sorry))

8.The storymode is semi hard. and bosses are dam fun once you know there trick's. you get 3 respawn coins once a day and they stack up (so now i got 10. respawn for days!)

9. The new lotto. Every hour you can claim a gift (normally ore's) that can be use for the lotto to get gun that last for 1-7 days or can be perma. you can also take appart the tier 1 guns to get the tier2 ore's and get the nice prim item's (so hot) but same thing for em'. last for 1-7 days or they can be perma (again so hot). This rewards the players who play gunz more o/c and the new players have abit more struggle (sorry newbies).

I hope to review more later on about this game later on. if you got any question's feel free to ask!"

reviewText:
GunZ 2...it's pretty much another eastern 3rd person shooter clone...and a very bad one at that.

GunZ 2 features 2 main modes...a PVP mode, and a PVE mode, and I honestly have trouble determining which one is worse. On one hand, the PVE mode is pretty bad. It's brutally diffucult. You pretty much die after taking 5 hits, so the learning curve is pretty high to start. But even the most experienced player will find it's impossible to clear the PVE mode because of the shockingly limited ammo supply characters have. With little to no way to restore ammo, you find yourself, one way or another, out of ammo, and forced to use your melee weapon...in a gunfight. Death usually follows shortly after that...and then the game will try to pressure you into buying revival tokens. Clearly, the PVE mode was crassly put together to force players to buy revival tokens. It will take close to 30 tokens to clear your average level, so unless you enjoy paying close to 60 dollars just to clear a level, I suggest you steer clear...

Despite how awful the PVE mode is, the PVP mode is worse. Basically, it's entirely pay to win.
Once you're dropped into a PVP round, which will most likely lag and stutter to a strong degree, you'll notice the only way to really get kills is to use a melee class, or a sniper rifle.
But not just any melee or sniper rifle, oh no! You need the special premium gear, which can only be obtained by using this game's abomination of a cash shop, the telsa shop." Basically
date: while other games charge you big bucks for game winning items
recommended: THIS game charges you big bucks for a CHANCE at game winning items.\nThe kicker? Even if you spend hundreds of dollars (which is
hoursPlayed: by the way
voteText: a low estimate of how much it will cost)\nand get lucky
helpfulPercent: there's no guaruntee that your class will even be able to use the item you get.\n\nBasically
votesHelpful: this game is a very expensive coin op. Pay for extra lives
votesTotal: or you can't have fun in PVE.\nPay for the best gear in the game
votesFunny: or you can't have fun in PVP.\nBest to stay far away from this game
commentsCount: unless you happen to enjoy flushing money down the toilet."

reviewText: After playing the First Duel back since 2002, I was addicted to the ways you can play, whether kodachi or katana or even dagger, all types of weaponry and armory as well.  Though the population favored katanas and Shotguns, always loving the Red Blood and single pistol for the challenge.  When MAIET announced this I got excited to think this would be a major updated version of it, with possibly the same weapons and armor, new stuff as well, updated graphics, When this game launched things have turned really quickly, feels more controlled instead of free.  Lack of gear, lack of fun...  Unfortunately now this game is just another empty lobby simulator.  I was also hoping a story that actually catches you, not something that you see from any other game.  I even remember when they promised that anything can be used as a weapon as well, including debris from the map, that had to be changed when MAIET lost a few members and so on...  Had potential, though not sure what the future is for GunZ2.

reviewText:
In my opinion this game shouldn't even be called Gunz 2, they should have slapped a new name on it because it's nothing like the original besides being able to dash and go pew pew. This game was broken by the classes they added and any sort of competetive aspect of this game is more about who can exploit class strengths and weaknesses.

Gunz one had a tough learning curve because there was actually things to learn, like how to lead shot, chain dashes, look for opportunities, and when to fight and when to run - fighting tooth and nail, gracefully. And I say that BEFORE taking into account K-style and the more difficult things to do in that game.

Gunz 2? Spam your skills, wait for an opportunity to cheese someone to death, and pay to win. Granted ijji-Gunz had the cash shop and some pretty OP gear from time to time it didn't RUIN the game if you were good in my opinion, and you could always go back to I-Gunz and stay on your server.

Gunz 2 is an embarassment to the name and the good memories from the years I spent playing the original Gunz, I'm surprised Steam has kept it on.  The only thing I could MAYBE give kudos to is the quest missions for the interesting boss fight and the attempted story line, but that's far from the reason anyone wants to play Gunz - not to mention it's just as buggy as the original Gunz quests...

reviewText: Gunz 2: The Second Duel is a sequel to the original Gunz which was released in 2003. This is a fast paced 3rd person shooter multiplayer game that allows you to execute gravity defying moves. Unlike the first Gunz many advanced techniques were removed and the game is now fit for casual and the more hardcore gamers on this franchise. Though free to play you can buy items from the microtransaction shop. There is a gambling system called the Tesla Shop, which uses purified ores and purified crystals, which are a type of currency in Gunz 2. This game has a player hosting system which allows players with the best suitable network to host the server, which may cause lag and is still a work in progress. There are so far 6 classes with different unique playstiles and different set of achievements, Gold and Ores are easy to get without using the microtransaction shop. Overall this game is fun to play with friends, and is suitable for both casual and hardcore gamers

reviewText:
Think Perfect World Entertainment. Think RNG and cash sinks.
And unbalanced PVP, with lag, with queue systems that half the time you spent doing nothing until you get into a session.
Melee in PVP is an absolute (even guaranteed) clusterf@!#. Oftentimes you don't even realized that the guy you're trying to hit may be your ally and that most players are using the same character with the same aesthetics / appearance.

Now we move onto the characters. Players can choose from a wide spectrum of characters each with their own playstyles and equipment restrictions (bar a few characters).
I like this part, but what imagine happens when you pit 2 players together, 1 comes with a sword, a slow firing and weak hitting sniper rifle, a rapid-firing but highly inaccurate after a few shots peashooter and the other a mace, a moderately fast-firing albeit slower a few margins, harder-hitting assault rifle carrying more ammo and a grenade launcher for the Lord's sake. Oh, and all the characters move so sluggish that everybody had to perform 'dashes' (double tap for...you know, dash, a la Megaman double tap dashing). Plus stun-lock melee. Guaranteed you'd stun-lock them to all Oblivion and get stun-locked in turn.

PVE. Close to Hazard Ops-style. But you don't stand a chance going Solo and that PVE balancing is so damn balanced, you'd think you're playing PVP but against dumber-than-dumb AI bots. And OP bosses. OP bosses with 1 hit KOs, x50 health bars and are superior bullet sponges. If you run out of Revival Coins (think coins for arcades, Metal Slug etc), don't expect to continue your session, just drop out in less than a set time or get kicked instead. Or pray your surviving teammates lose and get your exp. There's no option to purchase coins while in-game either and you can only get coins by purchasing them via microtransactions or daily log-in rewards. (You don't get them everyday.)

Market. I don't even know why'd they bother with the in-game currency (gold, currency farmed by playing and not real cash). Almost all the items of the same category cost the same. And very rarely those weapons are better compared to the rest. Gives off a sense of variety but you'd probably be disappointed, I know I am.

And let's talk about the lottery system. Players are probably better off with the market instead of this because most of the time you'd get a random timed item that may or may not help you at all which most of the time you'd get a timed version of an item readily available in the market. And you waste your hard-earned crystals and ores.
*Crystals and ores are used in the Tesla machine (lottery).
But if you're lucky, you'd get some of the mostly-coined 'privileged items'. Some looked pretty good, while some just plain look dumb. They even have a black / purple version of Captain America's mask-suit combo.

Graphics. They're okay but just so-so. They focus more on character details and lesser on the maps / background objects etc. Expect obvious mesh clippings, though.

Animations. While they, without doubt, look good, it is only so much good they could do. Animations are slow, ragdoll physics are sub-par, and check those legs out when they gun n' run, they even keep their backs straight up 90 degrees as if they're standing at attention.

Music. They're good, but I get the feeling that they lack drive or motivation. Like most of the time they don't even fit the theme or the situation players are in.

Voice acting. Honestly, I was shocked. They're pretty damn good when it comes to NPC dialogues in Campaign. Sadly, voice acting only kicks in in boss fights (towards the best of my knowledge). Player characters' voice acting? Some are okay, some just sound strained with shoddily imitated accents (Elena with the assault rifles and the noobtube). Not all of the characters speak the same language though. Some spoke English, some spoke Korean.

It lags in PVP, but not so in PVE because PVP groups you randomly with players from neighboring countries or globally. And when it lags, you gonna get wrecked. Stun-locks or group stun-locking, getting sniped off or riddled with bullets while downed. (Yes, you can shoot people doubled over to death and is highly encouraged. Apparently, people losing their footing is a close to sure fire way to donate points to the enemy team). And I think the only way to prevent that is to level up and get that level-specific skill to which that has escaped my mind.
Doesn't matter much, expect things to go wrong even when you've done it right.

Like some of the reviews here on Steam. Jiggly breast physics and underwear are among the few 'goods' here.

Player matchmaking in PVP. Aside from the notoriously, infamously 'queue' queuing system, you'd think they done good with the matchmaking. Nope. Good luck going against veteran players with the aforementioned 'privilege items' and better 1 hit KO skills and better stats. And lag. Usually, the enemy team might prefer to lag alongside their teammates instead of changing hosts. Why? They get to lag the entire session but with the chosen host as their chosen Hero. Because he isn't affected by the lag.

And player's are vulnerable to getting reported by temperamental players throwing fits of tantrum or just because they alone lagged (8 players, 7 doing fine, 1 lagging). Democracy don't work there, folks.

It has potential, but sadly, it may require an overhaul of the current build. I do not recommend it.
But hey, to each their own.

reviewText:
Different, but not bad.

The original Gunz was one of my favorite games of all time. One of the only reasons I quit playing it was due to some pretty bad carpal tunnel. I remember making myself learn to K-Style and D-Style. I remember going naked so I could carry 2 rocket launchers and lol spam rockets in death matches while flying off the walls. Gunz was a great time with an extremely high skillcap. So how does Gunz 2 match up?

The first thing I noticed was the movement. Although individual character movement seems slowed down the feel of combat is still extremely fast paced. You can no longer keep dashing into a wall to keep yourself afloat and dashing is much slower in this game with more time in between each dash. I remember being to dash 2-3 times in a single jump in Gunz 1, where in this I might get 2 sometimes.

The most obvious and controversal thing is the removal of K-Style. People who couldnt learn K-Style complained about it being a glitch and not suppose to be in the game. People that did learn found it to be a fundamental aspect of what made Gunz, Gunz. While K-Style is gone the overall idea of it still exists. K-Style was used because it was the ultimate offensive and defensive playstyle. You basically were a constant moving target that could not only defend but also attack very quickly with your sword. It essentially covered all your bases.

You can still block and move in Gunz 2 but not at the speed you used to. Also attacks are now comboed so you can not constantly butterfly to attack.

I will now explain the 2 main gameplay changes that seem to seperate it from Gunz 1.

First is that in Gunz 1, the sword was the main weapon. It did everything except attack at range. I've done and seen people kill multiple people just by butterflying even when they used guns. In Gunz 2 there is an increase movement to using ranged weapons. Your melee weapon is great when the enemy gets close, but anything outside sweep range you are basically wanting to stick to your guns.

Second is the more emphasis on team play. Gunz 1 was more about who had the best player. A single elite player could take on a team of 4 by himself in Gunz 1. This is no longer as easy in Gunz 2. The class system also further emphasizes it. I found the class system to be interesting and similar to TF2 in that basically every class has a counter.

Classes:

The Silent Avenger is basically your extreme range and extreme close range specialist. Their weapons are swords, SMG's, and Sniper Rifles. They are great at really far range sniping and when they get in close their SMG's and swords make quick work of enemies. They are not great at medium range or groups and their counter is the Gunslinger because she can basically defeat him at any range outside extreme close and extreme range.

The Shadow Dancer reminds me of the closest thing to Gunz other than the Silent Avenger. Quick and fast, she specializes on killing enemies that don't see her and is amazing against 1v1. A good tactical Shadow Dancer can take on multiple enemies quite easily with her decoy skill however. Her counter is the Silent Avenger. Better at ranged combat and having just as good melee, she has a hard time against SA's.

The Gunslinger is your ranged class obviously. Her Assault Rifle does great damage at medium range and her grenade launcher is the only current indirect weapon, meaning you can lob it around corners and other places too set up traps. She excels at ranged combat and against groups however she is poor 1v1 and at close range the high rate of fire of the SD and SA's weapons makes mincemeat of her. Her counter is the Shadow Dancer because she can easily get within the GS's range and jungle her to her doom.

Finally is the Shield Trooper. He is like the Heavy from TF2. He is amazing at close/medium range thanks to her Minigun and Flamer. He also excels at fighting groups. Where the gunslinger is better at medium/long-indirect fire, the Shield Trooper is better at Close-Medium range gun damage. He is kind of a wild card in terms of counters. He can easily get beat medium range against Gunslingers, but if he gets in range, youre boned. SD's can dash around him all they want but his health and no juggle make him hard to kill. SA's can snipe him, but if he gets close,, again, its a bad thing. Basically all classes counter him and he counters all classes.

Overall the gameplay reminds me of Gunz 1 with just a different feeling. It is without a doubt extremely fun. There wasn't a moment in the couple hours I've played so far that I was bored. The best way I can explain it is like Resident Evil series going from 3 to 4. 4 turned the game into more action oriented, but it wasn't a bad thing, it was quite good. It didn't feel like Resident Evil, but it was a fun game in it's own right. Gunz 2 doesn't quite feel like Gunz 1, but I think it will be a great game and I can already see people coming up with new techniques for it.

reviewText: This game is fun, don't get me wrong. I really love third-person shooters and it's a huge plus how fast-paced GunZ 2 is. But there's a problem with the way connection works here. In GunZ 2, the host server is a random player. There's no proper server that everyone connects to, therefore not all games will be fair (some refuse to change the host in fear that they will lose to better players, who are most likely lagging). Expect to be a decent player with a good kill-death ratio, but in some matches, go 3 kills with 12 deaths because the host's connection can't support itself plus 7 people.\n\nThat's the ONLY problem I have with it. I'd probably find myself playing this game more often if they just fixed that issue and got a proper server.

reviewText: I want to not recommend the game while recommending it. I was passionate about the first GunZ. It was the first game that I played extensively online and will always have a warm place in my heart, so I had a lot of expectations going into this game. It doesn't feel even in the slightest to be in any way similar to the first GunZ but it is still an okay game. The issue is the first installment in the series died out due to the mass amount of hacks that released for it and how easily it was to cheat. I played this game for a weekend and then the next weekend when I logged in I went four games straight with a hacker on my team or on the opposing one. It took a while for hackers to take over the first installment and it seems this will fall like the first had before it even gets a lot of attention, which is to say the least... pathetic.

reviewText:
For people out there asking 'Is this better than its prequel?' my answer is yes, but still not worth your god damned time. Maybe if it allowed for custom games or maybe if it had dedicated servers instead of letting some random guy host then maybe it would be worth it. But my experience so far after reaching level 8 is a mix of unsatisfaction and irritation. The game is decided almost immediately after it starts just by looking at who's the host and my corresponding ping to the said host and it's frustrating.

But I will not dwell more on that because thankfully the game gives me more to harp about.

Graphics:

Yes, the game indeed surpasses its original but you've seen this kind of detail before and even better. In fact, I can even dare say that this falls off compared to some games because there are some actions that are not rendered too well. The characters you can choose from are lack-lustered and it wouldn't be too annoying if you had morethan four to choose from, i am not too sure if you can change hairstyles later on cause as I said I am only level 8 but the inability to do so even at my level makes looking at my character a chore.

Plot:

The previous gunz didn't have this but now we have a campaign mode. It's always a good thing for me if a game has a single player mode that can help him burn his time while waiting for his friends but this campaign mode doesn't really hit that spot. The game just basically keeps spawning mobs and mobs of 'Adam Soldiers' at you until you die. Are there respawns? There are but you have to buy them with steam money.... Yeah, ♥♥♥♥ that. As I said this mode is repetitive and gets really boring really fast so I didn't even bother to finish up to the second chapter. Maybe I will when I get some of my friends to play with me. Hopefully they don't get bored and last at least two chapters.

Gameplay:

If Gunz 2 does something right it's this. Fighting with another player is intense and exciting. The different classes add variety and forces players to incorporate strategy into their game which the old GunZ didn't have. The class specific specials look amazing and feels amazing to use! One can feel like a total badass after slicing an opponent into half with a katana as the poor victim slowly kneels on the floor electrified before he dies. A successful and cunning illusionary escape with a shadow dancer feels very satisfying after you see your fooled foe die from the explosion your illusion creates! All of these plus the already amazing wall walking mechanics now improved to make continuos wall run possible without being a validictorian at the game. You can run from walls to walls just by properly positioning your mouse and pressing the jump button without having to pause and this makes for very flashy acrobatic kills!

Too bad though that no matter how good its gameplay is the fact remains that it only matters if your enemies don't stand in front of you and take the brunt of all your attacks and yet take no damage because you have too high ping due to the host living in the far side of the planet or because he has a dial up. Over and over you will hear complains in game about changing hosts and even if the host changes it's still not guaranteed that the next host will be more decent! Your only real salvation is if the system chooses you to host the game but even then, your experience will be mediocre as people who lag with you as host will soak up damage like the world's most porous sponge! Having dedicated servers instead of this kind of interface will fix this! There was lag back in the old gunz but not like this! This kind of lag makes the game almost unplayable as the good lag free games are very, very, rare.

Overall gunz is a good game but I cannot recommend this game with all the lag. It's free to play so it's safe to try but I wouldn't recommend buying bundles for it because chances are you will quit this game unless you're a hardcore fan of the prequel. However, I do recommend keeping this game in your memory because if the game fixes its lag problems then it's an experience worth your money.

reviewText:
Thank goodness this is free....because this game is seriously broken!

Negatives (some are subjective):
-You get stuck at the end of the game. This most likely happens to  the host of the game.
-You cannot pick a room. The game chooses a room for you randomly. If you leave a room chances are you can't enter the same one.
-Its stupid how you publish a game WHILE IT IS STILL IN DEVELOPMENT. The company could have at least have its own testers. THE GAMERS ARE BASICALLY TESTING THIS GAME AND THEY ARE ALREADY CHARGING REAL MONEY FOR SOMETHING THAT'S STILL DEVELOPING.
-Game in campaign is difficult even in very easy mode. The only way you're gonna win is if you have coins which cost real money. THERE IS NO HOPE OF WINNING SOLO ON CAMPAIGN UNLESS YOU GOT REVIVAL COINS.....DOZENS OF THEM. This game was made so you spend money to finish it. The developers might as well rob me. (This game was meant for the rich, hardcore community not casual gamers)
-Dashing and wall running does not make this unique. It really serves no purpose other than being eye candy. This game is a Devil May Cry wannabe.
-It's all about the firearms. Melee yields little success.
-I had a critical error happen. A window prompted me to send a report to the publishers. I wanted to but it was taking so long JUST TO SEND A REPORT. THAT SPEAKS VOLUMES WITH REGARDS TO THE QUALITY OF THE GAME.
-This game needs a vote-kick function when playing the maps. Some players will troll and not enter the rally point, running out the time which is frustrating.
-A game is NOT FUN if it has to make you GRIND to become better. If you want better equipment you have to buy it in the shop with gold (not real money). But then you have the problem with durability. You have to grind away at the game like a dumb robot to maintain your advantage. In other words, upkeep. GAMES ARE SUPPOSED TO BE FUN, NOT FRUSTRATING. You already have the daily grind of real life, now you have to grind in a game?

I'm a casual gamer. I have a life outside my monitor. So you would expect games to be fun and help you forget the troubles of the day. Not this one though. No I have not played the first GunZ.

My advice: Play it if you like a diluted" Devil May Cry type game but don't spend your hard earned cash on something that may not take flight.

I realize that being a free game the developers have to make some profit for their work
date: but seriously iron everything out in this game. I have no problem paying real money for a decent
recommended: enjoyable game.\n\nP.S. I DARE THE DEVELOPERS TO PLAY THIS "GAME" THAT THEY CALL AND SEE HOW IT MAKES THEM FEEL. DO NOT PAY TO WIN. PLAY LEGIT."

reviewText: As a forewarner, this game has quite possibly the worst netcode in existence. Seriously, if you aren't the host (it uses *peer-to-peer* hosting in 2014), your shots register about three-fourths of a second behind where you are currently looking, making it impossible to hit people whom are usually dashing about incessantly, meaning any character not focused on AoE or wide-arc melee will be left missing well over two-thirds of the shots tehy would have otherwise rightfully hit with. To test this yourself, play games until you get host, and notice your accuracy and kill ratio skyrocket astronomically when the game registers your shots properly.\n\nThe classes are an awful change to the GunZ system. reviewText:
For people out there asking 'Is this better than its prequel?' my answer is yes, but still not worth your god damned time. Maybe if it allowed for custom games or maybe if it had dedicated servers instead of letting some random guy host then maybe it would be worth it. But my experience so far after reaching level 8 is a mix of unsatisfaction and irritation. The game is decided almost immediately after it starts just by looking at who's the host and my corresponding ping to the said host and it's frustrating.

But I will not dwell more on that because thankfully the game gives me more to harp about.

Graphics:

Yes, the game indeed surpasses its original but you've seen this kind of detail before and even better. In fact, I can even dare say that this falls off compared to some games because there are some actions that are not rendered too well. The characters you can choose from are lack-lustered and it wouldn't be too annoying if you had morethan four to choose from, i am not too sure if you can change hairstyles later on cause as I said I am only level 8 but the inability to do so even at my level makes looking at my character a chore.

Plot:

The previous gunz didn't have this but now we have a campaign mode. It's always a good thing for me if a game has a single player mode that can help him burn his time while waiting for his friends but this campaign mode doesn't really hit that spot. The game just basically keeps spawning mobs and mobs of 'Adam Soldiers' at you until you die. Are there respawns? There are but you have to buy them with steam money.... Yeah, ♥♥♥♥ that. As I said this mode is repetitive and gets really boring really fast so I didn't even bother to finish up to the second chapter. Maybe I will when I get some of my friends to play with me. Hopefully they don't get bored and last at least two chapters.

Gameplay:

If Gunz 2 does something right it's this. Fighting with another player is intense and exciting. The different classes add variety and forces players to incorporate strategy into their game which the old GunZ didn't have. The class specific specials look amazing and feels amazing to use! One can feel like a total badass after slicing an opponent into half with a katana as the poor victim slowly kneels on the floor electrified before he dies. A successful and cunning illusionary escape with a shadow dancer feels very satisfying after you see your fooled foe die from the explosion your illusion creates! All of these plus the already amazing wall walking mechanics now improved to make continuos wall run possible without being a validictorian at the game. You can run from walls to walls just by properly positioning your mouse and pressing the jump button without having to pause and this makes for very flashy acrobatic kills!

Too bad though that no matter how good its gameplay is the fact remains that it only matters if your enemies don't stand in front of you and take the brunt of all your attacks and yet take no damage because you have too high ping due to the host living in the far side of the planet or because he has a dial up. Over and over you will hear complains in game about changing hosts and even if the host changes it's still not guaranteed that the next host will be more decent! Your only real salvation is if the system chooses you to host the game but even then, your experience will be mediocre as people who lag with you as host will soak up damage like the world's most porous sponge! Having dedicated servers instead of this kind of interface will fix this! There was lag back in the old gunz but not like this! This kind of lag makes the game almost unplayable as the good lag free games are very, very, rare.

Overall gunz is a good game but I cannot recommend this game with all the lag. It's free to play so it's safe to try but I wouldn't recommend buying bundles for it because chances are you will quit this game unless you're a hardcore fan of the prequel. However, I do recommend keeping this game in your memory because if the game fixes its lag problems then it's an experience worth your money.

reviewText: It's a good game, dont be hating, but could be better. Playing this game makes me happy and sad at the same time, GunZ had K-Style (yes i'm going to QQ about K-style, it was amazingly well and was what made the game exciting yet addicting) The level limit is quite annoying, and I wish it had more features from GunZ: The Duel, However, GunZ 2 : The Second Duel has unique additions along with frequent server monitoring and, apart from all the new features, it is in Early Acess. I've been waiting for around 8 years for this game, and I would recommend a 7 or 8 out of 10 ( 7/10 or 8/10), it could use some prequel features, but I believe the developers will not let their fans down on the upcoming game, so I keep my head high. Some might not be able to play this game due to the server cap being 1,500, but I HIGHLY doubt it will stay like this for a lot of time. Posting negative comments on the discussions help marvelously, but posting stupid, unevidental hate on this game not only annoys the community, but might aswell as the moderators and developers. Whilst it is ok to provide negative feedback on this upcoming game, keep in mind to be respectful to these people and to contribute with evidence. This game has more potential than GunZ: The Duel, with extra help from the fans of Maiet Entertainment, and while this game came out  on 2011 and has been translated for our own use in 2014, I still am priviledge to get a taste of the game and move along with the game aswell.

reviewerDisplayName: Quitting games, I won't be back
reviewText: Terrible. Simple as that. Any nostalgia I had for GunZ has been killed by this game. They removed every feature that was fun and replaced it with clunky, anti-fun mechanics that defeat any purpose in playing. Female models are smaller, faster, and better, as they were in the original, but to a degree I can't imagine. You now dash all the time, even when holding guns, which means the rolling dodges that could be shot at are replaced by laggy dashes.\n\nThe networking is just terrible. Enemies warp all over, the quick dashes become instant teleports and you quickly realize the mistake you've made installing this game. I was hoping to relive the GunZ experience I remember from five years ago, with some updated graphics, what I got was a trainwreck so bad I'm starting to wonder if I enjoyed the original either.

reviewText:
As a fan of the first GunZ game, I looked forward to this with cautious optimism. The gameplay itself is quite enjoyable. Campaign mode is fun, deathmatches are not bad, so long as you end up with people that aren't a much higher level than you and have reasonable pings.

That being said, even ignoring the difficulty getting into the server, there are still some pretty significant drawbacks. The class system, for one thing, is pretty awful. You are stuck with the class you choose at the start until you mange to accumulate 10k gold for all the other classes except shadow dancer, which you need 50k for (Unless you choose it initially). There appears to be some sort of crafting system, though I have yet to figure out how it works. You get 3 lives to use in campaign mode per period of time (I think probably per day, but I'm not sure). After that it is three dollars to bring yourself back to life. However, it is still quite fun.

All in all, the actual core game has some promise, but I'm pretty disappointed with the lag, class system, unintuitive item crafting, and the $3 pricetag on campaign mode continues.

votesHelpful: who wields a giant melee shield into battle. This shield may be a bit slow and boasting a low combo count
votesTotal: but it certainly hurts to get hit with. Not to mention he has the only block that completely protects against most firearms. His trade off is being one of the slowest classes and also having a pretty short reach with his firearms
votesFunny: though you can get some lucky shots with the minigun.\n\nBut I do like that each character is now unique. In the original Gunz
commentsCount: there were several classes to choose from but I never really noticed any difference between them besides what weapons they started off with (which could all be changed to whatever you wanted later on). Now I mentioned customization is a bit lax atm as all the classes are pretty much restricted to their own weaponry currently. I don't know if they plan to allow mixing up weapons later on or keeping them restricted to help make the classes stand out
column16: we'll just have to see where it goes.\n\nNow the only major drawback to this game so far has been on the server side of things. Unfortunately it is quite a bit difficult getting into the game (with the low server capacity cap
column17: currently only 4500). However another server side issue is the downside to peer to peer network. Unfortunately lag plays a huge factor when it comes to fast paced games and even with a strong connection
column18: you can end up with a nasty lag situation all depending on who the host is. There aren't really any official servers people play on but more so user hosted matches. This ultimately can lead to many instances where some players can connect just fine but others have horrible connections or spike all over the place
column19: simply because of the distance to the current host. Now the host can be changed via an option to help mitigate this issue
column20: but unfortunately you're still at the mercy of whoever is in the room. While someone's own internet may be pretty good
column21: that doesn't necessarily make them ideal hosts. Not to mention that the more people trying to connect to one game
column22: the worse a lag situation can get. I discovered this issue playing Tenchu Z on the Xbox 360. The multiplayer lag in that game increases expotentially depending on how many participants are in the group (max 4 players). At 4 players
column23: the game is essentially unplayable for anyone but the host. However when you remove that 4th person
column24: at 3 players the game is a lot more stable. Likewise dropping it down to 2 people
column25: depending on who is hosting
column26: there may be little to no lag at all. But it never mattered who was hosting or how good their connection was
column27: the second a 4th player was involved
column28: the match would always lag horribly.\n\nNow the devs for Gunz 2 are working on increasing the server capacity and trying to improve their network to help make the experience much more stable for everyone but that stuff takes time. However
column29: that is why the game is in an early-access stage (something many players tend to forget). There are many improvements to be made and stuff to add to the game to make it an amazing experience. However
column30: Gunz 2 certainly can be an amazing title as long as it could pull its act together and remain strong
column31: especially for a free-to-play title. Which by the way
column32: they took a bit note from the original Gunz in how to handle the free-to-play market. There was a big divide between players who bought their gear in game and players who purchased better gear using actual currency
column33: essentially creating a pay-to-win model. Though Gunz 2 handles this well by only having cosmetic things attached to the real currency
column34: while every gear piece can be purchased with in game currency. Definitely an improvement and something that lets many new players come enjoy the game without feeling at a disadvantage because they don't want to make a real money investment to a game they may or may not spend a lot of time with. Now people who want to put a little cash into their characters can help make themselves stand out and feel unique
column35: without gaining an unfair advantage over other players."

reviewText: It's a good game, dont be hating, but could be better. Playing this game makes me happy and sad at the same time, GunZ had K-Style (yes i'm going to QQ about K-style, it was amazingly well and was what made the game exciting yet addicting) The level limit is quite annoying, and I wish it had more features from GunZ: The Duel, However, GunZ 2 : The Second Duel has unique additions along with frequent server monitoring and, apart from all the new features, it is in Early Acess. I've been waiting for around 8 years for this game, and I would recommend a 7 or 8 out of 10 ( 7/10 or 8/10), it could use some prequel features, but I believe the developers will not let their fans down on the upcoming game, so I keep my head high. Some might not be able to play this game due to the server cap being 1,500, but I HIGHLY doubt it will stay like this for a lot of time. Posting negative comments on the discussions help marvelously, but posting stupid, unevidental hate on this game not only annoys the community, but might aswell as the moderators and developers. Whilst it is ok to provide negative feedback on this upcoming game, keep in mind to be respectful to these people and to contribute with evidence. This game has more potential than GunZ: The Duel, with extra help from the fans of Maiet Entertainment, and while this game came out  on 2011 and has been translated for our own use in 2014, I still am priviledge to get a taste of the game and move along with the game aswell.

reviewText:
Long winded review
Gunz: The Duel was an all time favourite of mine in terms of Online gaming. It had three things that would attract any testosterone filled young male to its seductive grasp: Guns, Swords, and acrobatically combining them along with flexible coats and scarves for extra Flair. I spent months grinding to level 20, relishing every battle and every lesson I learned to get that flexi coat. Naturally I felt inclined to play the long awaited sequel/reboot to theis all time high speed Third person shoot-em-up.
To specify a number of things the Original game had: there was a character customization system, with a wide array of weaponry and outfits each with attributes to suit different play styles, an incredibly high speed parkour system that required both skill to use and to shoot at, very reasonable ping games due to popularity and localization, as well as compatibility with most graphics cards due to the 2006-era appearance. On top of all this, Gunz' main draw was that it seamlessly (for its time) integrated the use of firearms and swords as weapons in battle, no fight was just a firefight or just a swordfight, each weapon type had strenghts and weaknesses to comabt each other, and players were required to use guile to use this to their advantage.
What does New GunZ2 has? Does it back this up, Does it immprove on this? does it have an even better system?
No.
character customization? enjoy having a selection of one of four racial sterotype, cookie cutter, CLASS BASED, Actors"

reviewText: This game is amazing. After the 5 year wait, I can say, the game has delivered on the hype. Seeing all the effort the team made by developing such a great starting screen, full of expensive lightning particles (must have taken many years to develop that), and bright lights, has truly made me understand why it took so long to make the sequel to Gunz 1. The starting screen is so amazing that you won't even be mad when you can't get past the screen because your keyboard does not contain 'any key'. Once Riot finally allows you to enter the game, you'll be greeted with an amazing lobby system and a full functioning cash shop that will provide you with all the great items to smash your enemies (you don't even need to spend time to get the items!) After spending hours upon hours of trying to start a game, I finally called it a night. Will play this game again tomorrow and you should too!
